talk.title: 10 tips to become an awesome Technical Lead
talk.description:
As you grow in your career, chances are that one day you will end up as the Technical Lead of 1 or more projects. Often not by choice. The role of Technical Lead is quite different from the role of (senior) Software Developer and this talk will bring you answers on questions like:

* How do I do technical interviews?
* How do I lead a team? How do I lead multiple teams?
* How do I cope with my new responsibilities?
* How do I cope with success / failure?
* How do I prevent losing focus on the technical challenges?
* ...

In summary, everything you want(ed) to know on your first day as a Technical Lead and that you can use every day from that point onwards.
talk.notes:
I've been a Technical Lead for over 10 years .. a role I never requested. I worked with small teams (2 people) and with larger teams (20+ people) as a Technical Lead. And a couple of times, I needed to do some firefighting on other projects, because of the missing experience of the Technical Lead (eg. when leading a team of offshore developers).

I started a Technical Lead training program when I was back at HP to overcome issues senior developers are likely to face when becoming a Technical Lead (eg. how to do technical interviews .. Which questions are useful? Should you focus on the resume? etc. ).

I would like to share my personal experience on this topic, because I believe a good Technical Lead is a key role within most (/ all) development teams.
talk.abstract: Everything you want(ed) to know on your first day as a Technical Lead and that you can use every day from that point onwards.

ratings.comments: If the content of this talk is kept narrow enough, this would be a really interesting talk.  However like other reviewers, I don't think a 15 minute talk that turns into a list of (say) 10 items will be very effective.  Better to pick the top 3 and have something that people will remember and enough time to tell some memorable stories.
Sounds like a good talk and introduction to something software architects needs awareness on. Good fit with SATURN.

The speaker definitely has some good experience to share regarding the role of technical lead and how it interacts with the architecture role.

Unfortunately, I don't believe that the '10 tips' format is right for SATURN.  I would love to hear a talk on the topic that was more focused on an audience of architects.
I don't see the tie to Software Architecture.  If he was a Software Architecture tech lead, then I could see the relevant tie.
I would very much like to see this 15-minute talk narrowed to fewer questions, all in a single area -- any of technical reviews, dealing with people, planning, etc.
Find the topic relevant, its experienced based, but hard to see how it relate to architecture and what are the takeaway from attending the talk. I have also some doubts about 15 minutes length.
These are all interesting topics for architects as leaders but also interesting to glean from books and available leadership literature.

The topic sounds interesting and pragmatic.

However it is not clear on how the topic is related to one of the topic themes for this year's conference. 

https://www.sei.cmu.edu/saturn/2017/call.cfm

In case the author could justify and provide more clarity I would think of considering it for a short time slot.

feedback.body:
Bart-

Thanks for your submission!

Your proposal sounds interesting, but I'm concerned about squeezing 10 tips into 15 minutes. Have you given this talk before?
I'm also concerned that this topic comes up a lot in blogs and other forums - how is your talk going to be different?

Thank you.

Hi John,

Thank you for considering my proposal.

It is a brand-new talk. I will present it, for the first time, in Riga, in a 50 mins slot.
I have experience with "slicing" talks into different time frames. For a 15 mins slot, I'd focus on the key takeaways and invite those interested to discuss the 10 tips in detail after the talk. Should you prefer it, I can also do 5 tips in more detail during the slot.

My talk will be different, because all the tips will come from personal experience. I've been a technical lead for different projects (in size, budget, team composition, location, ...)  for the past 10 years and I want to share my personal "lessons learned". 

Kind regards,
Bart Blommaerts

Thanks for the proposal. The topic sounds interesting and pragmatic.

From the guidelines for the conference could you please elaborate on how the topic is related to one of the topic themes for this year's conference. Link given at the end for your reference.

One of the themes talk about “how to ensure that architecture work gets done in environments without formal architect roles”. Is the talk about role of the Team Lead in an environment with or without a formal Architect? Also, what is not fully clear is whether the talk is about some of the management related activities a technical lead need to do or much on the technical side with or without an Architect.

Similarly, there is a theme that talks about “developing software architects, including coaching, mentoring, certification, professional training, and college education”. Is that the area the topic is going top focus.

Would it make sense to split the talk on roles and responsibilities of the technical lead without the interviewing aspects, as that would allow better focus for the limited time. I am also concerned about the 15-minute time window.

https://www.sei.cmu.edu/saturn/2017/call.cfm

Hello Yogeshwar,

Thank you for your feedback. Those are really good and useful questions!

When first submitting this talk, I intended to make two versions: a high-level version, suitable for a 15 mins slot and a more in-depth version, suitable for a 50 mins slot. For Saturn, I wanted to do the high-level version and invite the attendees to discuss the different tips in detail after the talk.

However, I like your idea of splitting the talk in two talks: 
- Focus on the roles and responsibilities of the technical lead (related on "build"): eg. architecture without having a formal architect role + governance over this architecture. This is (coincidentally) exactly what I'm doing in a current Microservices project for the biggest telecom operator in Belgium (IoT project in the smart automotive area). 
- Focus on the management aspect of a technical lead: eg. the interviewing process, facilitating estimations, etc.

I can do both talks, if you would like me to. I will likely split my "in-depth" version in these two topics as well. So thanks again for your feedback.

Most content of the talk(s) will come from personal experience and I intend to give a lot of anecdotes, personal stories and of course the "lessons learned" from these.

Kind regards,
Bart Blommaerts
Thanks for the details! All the Best!

I find it relevant and interesting but is concerned with 15 minutes. I would have liked to see the five core takeaways, and how does this role relate to the architecture of the actual system?

//Einar

Hello Einar,

Thank you for considering my proposal. It appears that PaperCall does not share the questions and comments from reviewers, because I received very similar comments from Yogeshwar Srikrishnan and John Klein. But that really shows the question is spot-on :)

My initial goal was to give 10 high-level tips and then invite the interested attendees to discuss more in-depth after the talk. But after the feedback from you and your colleagues, I proposed to split the talk in two talks:

1. Focus on the roles and responsibilities of the technical lead (related to “build”): eg. architecture without having a formal architect role + governance over this architecture. This is (coincidentally) exactly what I’m doing in a current Microservices project for the biggest telecom operator in Belgium (IoT project in the smart automotive area). 

2. Focus on the management aspect of a technical lead: eg. the interviewing process, facilitating estimations, etc.

I can do both talks, or the one you and your colleagues esteem best suited.


I'd like to thank you for your feedback, because I believe its really valuable. I do hope the different reviewers share their comments and my responses to them. It would be a shame if the responses got lost, due to the way PaperCall shares them.


Kind regards,
Bart Blommaerts

Thank you for the submission. It's great to share your experience and expertise in leading architecture-related projects. This submission can fit into topics dealing with the process of architecting in either track 1 or 3.

I share the concerns of some of the other reviewers (whose comments I am able to read in PaperCall, by the way) about content versus time. I like the questions you pose in the abstract, but it may be difficult to give them all enough attention in 15 minutes for audience members to get enough information to really absorb and later apply the answers. I like the idea of splitting the talk. 

If you stick with the short, 15-minute TED-style talk, please consider focusing on fewer questions in one particular area -- any of technical reviews, dealing with people, planning, etc. Alternatively, consider expanding the  presentation to a 30-minute experience report. I realize that you have plans for two versions, and were targeting the shorter version for SATURN.

Hi Anthony,

What would Saturn prefer?

a) 30 mins talk on "10 tips"
b) 15 mins talk on 5 "technical" tips
c) 15 mins talk on 5 "management" tips

I can do 2 talks (b and c) if Saturn would like me to. All content will be influenced a lot by my personal experiences. I never had the opportunity to attend Saturn, so it's difficult to determine the best match with the above choices. I'll happily write two abstracts (b and c) if needed.

Regards,
Bart Blommaerts

Hi Bart,

I'd expect either (b) or (c) to work out best. Other reviewers, please add your thoughts.

You have more information too, so if you find you have more time during the talk, you can always add a bonus tip or two. No one will complain if you advertise five tips and deliver six or seven!.

I'm hoping to hear what experience or problem led to each situation and what resulting tip resolves the problem. I want to hear more than just a flat list of tips. I want to hear your great stories behind them.

Hey Anthony,

Spot on. The number is actually not 10 tips .. but that's the first tip :)


Bart

Hi Bart,

This talk sounds interesting but appears to be aimed at new technical leads rather than architects.

As an experienced architect what do you think that you would take away from this presentation?

In your description you hint at an interesting architectural perspective regarding the importance of the role, such as the firefighting required due to the lack of good technical leads.

Is it possible to re-frame the talk to aim it more specifically at the architect?  For example, what roles do you think the architect plays in the development of good technical leads?  Do you believe that developing technical leads is an essential step towards developing good architects?#

Regards, 


Ged

Hi Ged,

I believe an architect needs to be part of the team, responsible for "creating" the system. In agile projects, this means being part of every sprint that needs architecturally significant decisions. In order to do this successful, a good collaboration between the technical lead and the architect is necessary. What I've regularly seem in practice, is that both roles are not always present in the same team: some projects might be to small (budget, man days, scope, ...) while many others are organised sub-optimal. One of your review-colleagues also pointed this out.

Both roles have some things in common (eg. leadership) and some of the tips I want to provide, should assist in creating this synergy: as a technical lead pay attention to architectural decisions, collaborate on the decision-making process. Get involved. You can see that this requires a different approach with or without a formal architectural role. I too often saw technical leads putting all their focus on "tools" and "frameworks" and I believe this alone is not enough to deliver successful systems (and sometimes it can be enough). Leadership is about being able to delegate, collaborate (with architects, developers, business people, ... stakeholders). An architect should embrace working with a technical lead, guide him, elevate him. And a technical lead should also embrace working with an architect: support him with technical options, ...

I strongly believe collaboration will aid both roles to perform better and become better. The roles have both similarities and differences. And that's a really good thing.

Regards,
Bart Blommaerts

Hi Bart,

Thanks for replying.  I completely agree regarding the importance of good collaboration between the roles.

Regards, 


Ged

talk.title: Accessibility Testing Tools for Developers
talk.description:
You don't have to be an accessibility expert to make your projects accessible, but you do have to make your projects accessible. 

Identifying accessibility issues as early as possible can save an organization or project a substantial amount of money, time, and headaches over trying to augment a web site or application after initial development. Using a testing tools during development for accessibility will definitely help with this process. 

For developers that are novice to web accessibility this presentation is a great introduction into key aspects to consider while developing. For developers that are more familiar, this presentation exposes tools that will make accessibility easier. All users will gain from learning how to build accessibility into their development workflow using a variety of testing tools, from simple to intricate.
talk.notes: This is generally a 60 minute presentation that can easily be expanded to fill 90 minutes.
talk.abstract: You don't have to be an accessibility expert to make your projects accessible, but you do have to make your projects accessible. This presentation can serve as an introduction to web accessibility by exposing what to look for, via a variety of tools, to help developers make projects inclusive to all
talk.talk_format: Tech Talks and Tech Tutorials (30 or 90 minutes - please specify the exact time in the Notes section)

ratings.comments: I think this would perhaps fit in a 30 minute presentation. 90 minutes are probably to long. If condensed into a 30 minute talk for architects, it would be a good fit for SATURN.

I think the topic of accessibility testing is valuable and architects should have exposure to it.  But at present it is hard to tell what you're going to cover, whether it will be relevant to me and what I'll learn. 

Can you extend the description to provide more information on what the talk actually covers?  Given that it can be 60 or 90 minutes, it would also be worth clarifying what you would include or exclude in the two forms.

I would love to hear a talk on Accessibility from an architectural perspective.  Something to spark more discussion regarding this quality attribute. 

Unfortunately this talk appears to be focused on development, which is of less interest.
I don't see the tie to software architecture.

I find this topic relevant. There is a question if it should be done as an introduction, aimed at architects or more as a in depth workshop aimed at coders. 

What are the you guys thinking?
Topic is relevant and important. Details for a 90 minute slot are sparse.

feedback.body:
Hi Einar, thank you for your consideration. Perhaps an intro to web accessibility would be better suited, if you feel it is a unknown subject to the audience? If not, I can gladly add a few lines to describe the purpose and benefits.

Regarding the duration, 90 minutes would allow me more time to go through the code demonstration at then end, the gran finale, which is usually rushed due to questions/ conversations throughout the presentation.

Please let me know if you need additional information. Again, thank you for your consideration.

Thank you Gerard. It might be the case that a introduction is better. There are more software architects than programmers here. But lets see what the other PC members think. In its current form, I think a 90 minute workshop is better than a 60 minutes. In introduction to the topic I guess is better done in 30 minutes.

Einar, since there are more architects than programmers then maybe this isn't the right forum for my presentation? My presentations on web accessibility are for front-end engineers using HTML, CSS, and JS that impact end-users. Software architect are a little too high level for this information. Thoughts?

Hi Gerard,

As an architect I'm curious, because I believe that accessibility is such an important quality attribute.  However, I'm not so interested in the implementation details.

I would love to see a talk provide an good, practical overview of the topic for the architect.  This is an area of debate for architects, so I think it is a very relevant field for discussion.

For example, in the first addition of "Software Architecture in Practice" the statement was made: "Making a system's user interface clear and easy to use is primarily a matter of getting the details of a user's interaction correct … but these details are not architectural."

In later editions this position was retracted with a section called "Usability Mea Culpa (or that’s not Architecture)" but other architects still disagree.  Consider this blog post that insists that usability is important, but still not architecture: http://enterprise-it-architecture.blogspot.co.uk/2013/04/usability-is-not-architecture-quality.html

As somebody with a passion for and experience of achieving accessibility, could you explain to architects why this is an important quality attribute and the role that architects play in improving it?

If you could include some well defined quality scenarios [1] and relevant architectural tactics [2] that would be very desirable.  The testing approach would be covered by the tactics and you might want to focus on this in particular.

I appreciate that this would be quite a deviation from your current proposal.  You may think of something closer to what you already have that will help to convince architects that this is something they need to be interested in.

[1] http://www.informit.com/articles/article.aspx?p=1959673&seqNum=4
[2] http://www.informit.com/articles/article.aspx?p=1959673&seqNum=5

Hi Ged,

I can understand why architects do not feel that usability, or UI, belongs in the realm of architecture. I can tell you from my own personal experiences that bad/ lazy service architecture can definitely impact and lead to bad UI. A lot of times, these things are in the name of security or performance and sometimes they can be smoothed over on the front end, but most times they can't. Speaking as a Front-End architect, performance is just as much a part of usability as accessibility is. 

I would agree that implementation of accessibility will not be of any interest to most architects, unless they are front-end like myself. But if you are interested in having the discussion of how bad architecture could lead to bad usability, I certainly have a few anecdotes that I could share.

There was a great [talk on globalization last year at SATURN](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KPabgSykvD8&list=PLSNlEg26NNpy1RjhlISNMRNO1gypYaXHo).  I like the idea of talks that try to find connections between architecture design and UX design.

Having gone through some accessibility training I do think there are architectural concerns and many of the trade-offs Gerard mentioned come to bear.  At the same time, it seems that most of web accessibility is related to implementation details - color choice, proper tagging, good naming, navigation orders for JAWS, etc.

I think the goal for most SATURN attendees would not be to become an accessibility expert, but to learn enough to not make bad trade-offs as Gerard mentioned (e.g. security over accessibility) or at least be aware that trade-offs are happening.  The proposed talk will go into significant detail that I don't think will be of general interest.  I realize that's a little sad since this is an important topic.  I think a shorter talk that gives a good overview and emphasizes the top things an architect should know might be a better fit for the audience.

Gerard -- What are your thoughts for your proposal based on the feedback?  I do hope some of the feedback was helpful.

Regards,

Michael

talk.title: Agile With Architecture
talk.description:
Over the past few years, there is a question central to many discussions surrounding agile approaches to architecting software: In agile process, is the architecture of the system designed up-front, or does it emerge over time as the result of the agile software development process? Also there is an importance of supporting evolution and change to a software-intensive system, and the practical implications of creating a change-ready system. The ability to adapt these changes is driven by two factors, Architecture and Agile Practices. This presentation shows some of the techniques an architect can use to be effective in the fast moving agile environments.
1.	A hybrid form combining both explicit and emergent architectural techniques. This approach explains
	      (i) How alignment is the part of architectural work where an architect makes sure that the solution fits its mission?
	      (ii) How distilling the direction of change, and designing the domain essence are explicit architectural activities?
	      (iii) How creating the detailed structure, and designing the domain essence can be done in an emergent way
2.	Trace the history of software development practices from waterfall phases through iterative design to agile techniques. These include
	      (i)The implementation of a project lifecycle selection framework
	      (ii) An approach for tailoring any defined method
	      (iii) A consideration of all elements of a development environment
	      (iv) Incremental adoption of change
	      (v) The implementation of a CoE (Center of Excellence)
3.	How to identify the right amount of architecture by looking at the problem being addressed from a different perspective?
4.	How to minimize rework through reasonable foresight and prototypes?
5.	How to accelerate delivery through early integration, continuous testing and automated deployment pipeline?
talk.notes:
Over the past few years, I am working on projects where the requirements are not fully defined up front. Also we are following an iterative approach to refine the requirements. So creating architecture and bringing the changes in each iteration is a real challenge. In this talk, I am going to talk about how the hybrid technique (using explicit and emergent architecture) will help to overcome some of the challenges. Also my talk will be based on the challenges I am facing on my current projects. 

This presentation is for 15 minute and is mainly intended for intermediate level audience.
talk.abstract: In agile process, is the architecture of the system designed up-front, or does it emerge over time as the result of the agile software development process? The ability to adapt and innovate is driven by Architecture and Agile Practices. This paper shows the techniques an architect can use in agile.

ratings.comments: Much discussion and feedback, yet there's still concern.  I can't find any talks by him on Youtube or any blogs etc.  Given that he's not nailed the focus, the topic has been covered at Saturn for a decade, and he appears to be a new speaker, I think there's too much risk of embarrassing failure here.

This sounds very interesting

Architecture's contribution (or otherwise) to agility is a topic that has been explored many times in print and at conferences.  Could you make it clear how your talk relates to those that have gone before and what is new and novel about it.

A significant concern I have about the current description is that it simply won't fit into 15 minutes.  You need to narrow it down to a couple of key messages if you want to present it in this format.

This another talk addressing the question in the "Digital, Virtual Software Architect": How can we be effective in fast-moving agile environments?

My only concern is the time available.  There seems to be a lot to cover in just 15 minutes.
Seems like it is covering too much for 15 minutes.

This talks needs better focus. As proposed, it is covering a wide range of information in only 15 minutes. That will not result in a powerful talk.

Focus may be narrowed and improved based on feedback.

feedback.body:
Thank you for the submission. Agile architecting is a topic of interest as development times continue to shorten.

Could you explain more about what type of agile development you are addressing? You have mention "agile software development process" (lowercase agile) and "Agile Practices" (uppercase Agile). There can be differences, and audience members may make incorrect assumptions. Will the talk address how architecting activities relate to some specific Agile methods (for example, sprints) or is it more about architecting in a less strictly defined but still rapidly changing environment?

It may be difficult to present all the proposed content in 15 minutes. The abstract describes five topics, some with subtopics. If you need to shorten it, I suggest that the history information (waterfall to iterative to agile) could be trimmed out. That is information audience members can find in other places (for example, on the Web).

How you specifically combined architecting tasks and work produces with agile timelines, and how you are able to continually revise the architecture without big tear ups and lost work will be most valuable to audience members. I suggest a focus on those aspects (that is, your topic 3).

For which track is this talk proposed? Track 1 or 3 seem applicable.

Thank you for the feedback. Please see below my answers to your questions.

In this topic, I was trying to address how architecting activities relate to Agile Software Development (ASD) methods (for example Scrum). In other words  how architects can be effective in iterative, incremental and evolutionary development . I agree that it is difficult to cover the topics I put in my abstract in 15 minutes. So I am thinking of concentrating what you proposed which is mostly on topic 3. So here I will concentrate more on how to continually revise the architecture without big tear ups and lost work or how to avoid design erosion.  

I think this will fit on Track 1 (how architects can be effective in fast-moving, agile environments)

So here is my revised abstract on this topic.

Over the past few years, there is a question central to many discussions surrounding agile approaches to architecting software: In agile process, is the architecture of the system designed up-front, or does it emerge over time as the result of the agile software development process such as Scrum? However, according to the followers of Agile Software Development (ASD) methods, upfront design and evaluation of Software Architecture are likely to consume lot of time and effort without providing a valuable deliverables. The proponents of Software Architecture believe that sound architectural practices cannot be followed using agile approaches. This presentation shows how software architects embrace change by systematically altering design activities with iterative architecture assessment and refactoring.
Thanks for the reply! Good luck!

I like the revised focus as it relates to a significant challenge for software development. Would you say a little more about your “different perspective?” Does this relate to any other tools/techniques that would give the reviewers a sense of your approach (for example, there has been a lot of attention lately to addressing the challenges if ASD with scaled agile frameworks). Relating how the technique helps you with challenges you are facing on your current projects is an effective way to communicate your story. Would you say a little more, perhaps about an anecdote that you might use?

Can you confirm that this is intended as a 15 minute talk? We have had some issues with talk format being changed on edit. Please updated your submission to indicate the correct talk format and note the length in the Notes section as well.

DEV@SATURN Talk (15 minutes)


Audience Level
Intermediate
You are nailing it down, but 15 minutes is not a long time. You have basically 5 slides, what are the titles on those slides.

Basically in this talk I am going to talk about the "Variability" technique which we follow in our projects to adapt change in ASD.
Variability is interpreted as "anticipated and preplanned change" which is identified by looking into a number of similar but not identical systems from different usage or deployment scenarios.

The following are the titles for the 5 slides which I am planning.

Slide 1: Introduction of Variability Technique (i.e., locations in the architecture where change might occur)

Slides 2-5 are for handling variability.

Slide 2: Architectural Analysis (explains how to conduct initial variability analysis and create initial variability profile)

Slide 3: Architectural Synthesis (explains about proposing architecture solutions for the architecturally significant requirements identified during architectural analysis)

Slide 4: Architectural Evaluation (explains about examining architectural decisions against architecturally significant requirements)

Slide 5: Architectural Implementation and Maintenance  (explains about implementing initial architecture, elicitation of new variability requirements, revising architecture variability profile and refactoring architecture)

talk.title: A Hands on Introduction To Docker
talk.description:
Have you heard the term "container" without a full understanding of what it means? This is the place for you. This session will provide some of the theory of containers and provide a supervised hands on experience where participants will construct a Docker container. They will execute the container and save it in a repository so that they can some day show their children - "This was my first container".

Participants should have preloaded Docker and run the Hello World application
talk.abstract:
Containers are light weight virtual machines that have become default packaging mechanisms for the deploying of systems. Docker is the pre-eminent container system. 

I will provide some explanations of how containers work and the participants will build,execute, deploy, and save a container.

ratings.comments:
I think we should do a session on containers, hands on. Len would give definitely a great session. It's a yes so far. 

I think the title is problematic. There are Docker 101 tutorials and vidoes all over (e.g. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VeiUjkiqo9E). Having Intro to Docker in the program when someone is deciding to come to SATURN isn't going to look good.  

I suggest that the title be changed to reflect the totality of what the session is going to address. Having your first Docker container deployed should be the cherry on top because that can be accomplished in under 30 minutes. The session is about a deep understanding of the underlying principles of containerization.

Containers are certainly a a topic of interest but I can't believe that many SATURN attendees won't have done Get Started with Docker.  Can you expand the description to explain what this talk does beyond the basics?

It would also be very interesting to hear how the use of containers affects the qualities of the architecture - this is what many SATURN attendees need to understand and what isn't covered in any of the basic tutorials or overviews.

Given the speaker, I'm confident that this hand's on session will be given architectural relevance.

I think it would be particularly useful when paired with Avantika Mathur's 'Microservices and Docker at Scale' tech talk.
This fits in the tools track and also with the proposed workshop.

The presenter seems to have good experience in presenting. However a topic like "Introduction to Docker" sounds preliminary though the presenter promises to cover advanced topics as well.  I would think of renaming the topic as well as clarifying the details around the presentation coverage.
I have enjoyed many talks by Len. Its good to go for me.

Knowing Len this looks like a good session.  As we discussed in the comments the emphasis is on the conceptual differences between traditional VMs and containers, and will also touch on some of the networking abstractions.  Unless there is a more detailed "hands on with Docker" session I recommend this one.

feedback.body: Hi Len, how will this session go beyond the typical "Introduction to Docker" tutorials?

Michael - it doesn't really. When I participated in the workshop on containers at SATURN 2016, I came away with the impression that most of the handpicked participants had never used Docker or taken the basic tutorial. So it seemed like a service.

It differs slightly in that there is an emphasis on IP addresses. I have a Javascript program  that the attendees would use. It prints out ip addresses from inside a container . This emphasizes the key differentiator between the new use of the word container and the old use of that word.

Thanks for the additional details!

Yes, that was an odd group in last year's workshop -- quite the mix of people with different backgrounds.

Thanks for the topic. 

Would the presentation also touch base on the Container Ecosystem?? 
https://www.papercall.io/cfps/220/submissions/6278#
Example: 
Container Orchestration, Cloud Services Providing Docker Support, Container Image Registry, Monitoring and AutoScale Aspects

Considering this as a conference for Architects, would it be more appropriate to include some additional topics?

There is a difference what the presentation will touch on and the hands on portion. The hands on portion is simple use of docker.

The presentation will touch on Docker Swarm, EC2 Container Support and Lambda.

Hi Len!  I have a few suggestions: 

1) If attendees are going to use their laptops, at some point they'll need clarification on how to load docker. For folks with Windows 7, it's particularly cumbersome because you need Oracle VM VirtualBox or similar, since "Docker for Windows" only runs on Win 10. 

2) Show the docker architecture and clarify docker terminology: Docker image, container, docker registry, docker image repository, Dockerfile. Some of the terms get confusing especially when a container orchestration tool is in the mix and adds new terms. 

3) Examine the challenges and benefits of containerization.

4) In the notes section, consider including an outline of your talk, even if it’s only tentative.

Paulo

Paulo - all good suggestions except for giving advice on how to load Docker. I want them to have loaded Docker beforehand and I would just put a pointer to the Docker load instructions. When I assigned Docker in class, the students (MSE) were able to get it loaded, mostly without a problem.

talk.title: An invisible app? An Introduction to Inclusive Design & Fundamental User Experience Best Practices
talk.description:
An invisible app? An Introduction to Inclusive Design & Fundamental User Experience Best Practices
I know what you're thinking. You want to know what the triple-A app titles already know. It's Inclusive Design, a process to deliver intuitive usability; it is the heart-and-soul of great User Experience and innovative interactions. Your app is in a cosmic battle with the Uninstall button; inclusive design changes the nature of your app, tipping the scales in your favor. Appeal to your largest audience, provide cohesive experiences, and reduce development costs. It is an investment with one of the best returns in all of software. It's simple, cheap and awesome.

Application security is fundamental to software from initial design to every line developed. Security should not be an afterthought. Similarly, usability has this same ubiquity throughout the life-cycle of software. The fastest, most secure, most scalable software can end up in the trash because it misses the most important success criteria for any program in the universe - user acceptance. Software architecture profoundly impacts usability. Usability profoundly impacts acceptance. Architects may not choose app colors, error messages, and device layout, but they certainly make choices that enable and constrain designers options that make our software better. Like security is everyone’s responsibility at some level, so is usability at some level.

What will attendees learn? Inclusive design isn’t only usability; it’s recognizing that your user base changes as their social and environmental contexts change. If your user is standing in the sun, waiting for a train in the snow, holding a baby, riding a bus, visiting a library or watching the big game in a sports bar, applications can account for the one type of user that, given a certain context, looks and acts like another type of user. Inclusive design helps developers understand these contexts. It applies these to our implementations to add modalities, flexibility in workflows, and intentional tolerance for user mistakes. Developers will learn to recognize contextual assumptions and apply new, potential contexts to their existing user base so they can serve them best while consequently serving a new, larger user base.
talk.notes:
This is a 90 minute talk.

The structure of the talk includes:
1. Introduction to basic user types
2. Introduction to core user contexts
3. Examples of design assumptions
4. Examples of coding mistakes
5. Examples of app wins
6. Easy changes to the UI you can make today
7. Easy changes to the code you can make today
8.  Fundamental changes to code you can make next time
talk.abstract: I know what you're thinking. You want to know what the triple-A app titles already know. It's Inclusive Design, a process to deliver intuitive usability.

ratings.comments:
I think this topic would be of interest at SATURN but I'm not entirely sure and the description here didn't really help me to decide.

Firstly your abstract needs to be a bit longer and more engaging to explain what people will learn in and take away from the session.

Secondly, I'm not quite sure what the interplay between inclusive design and architecture is.  At first glance (and from my previous limited knowledge) I thought it was part of UX.  So while something that architects might have an interest in, probably not something they'd do themselves.  I take your point that it needs to be everyone's business, but what I can't tell is the impact on architecture.  Will you be focusing on how the architecture enables or constrains inclusive design?  I think that would make the talk very relevant.

In its current form, I'm not sure how many SATURN attendees would choose it.

Finally it is a 90 minute talk.  Will it be interactive at all?  Can it be made so?  90 minutes is quite a while for people to concentrate and take a lot away.
Seems this talk is more about User GUI Design and User Acceptance.  If the he could tie the talk to Architecture, it could be useful.

Not enough information. Seems to be about standard UX without a clear connection to architecture.

Update: After reading some of the comments from the proposer, this seems interesting but I hesitate to give my full endorsement for a 90 minute talk on these topics.
Find it hard to understand what he want to talk about, and I can't see any responses to the good questions asked so it is a nogo for me now.

feedback.body:
Jerry -
A couple of questions:
- Are you proposing a 30-minute or 90-minute talk? Unfortunately, there is no way to specify this in the submission template - seems like a less-than-inclusive design?

- Your proposal doesn't say much about your talk. How will you structure the talk, e.g., a running example? What will attendees learn, e.g., do you have a design process or checklist? 

- SATURN attendees are software architects, not UX designers. What is in this talk for an architect?

Thank you.

Thank you for your submission. 
I have a few suggestions from the perspective of a conference participant looking at the conference program:

1) Because SATURN is focused on software architecture, the word design is more readily associated with software architecture design. In your talk, design is User Interface design if I'm not mistaken. Not a problem, but it would avoid someone the confusion if you explicitly said UI desing somewhere (example: "Inclusive UI Design"). 

2) In the Description, it would be useful to qualify app as "mobile app" in at least one place. 

3) This sentence is not clear to me: "inclusive design changes the nature of your app, tipping the scales in your favor."  I'm not sure changing the nature of my app is a goal to pursue. What I want primarily is to improve its quality (usability, performance, badwidth utilization, power consumption, portability, maintainability, security, etc.).

In the notes section, consider including an outline of your talk, even if it’s only tentative.

This is really great feedback. Consider security. It is fundamental to software from initial design to every line developed. Security is not an afterthought. Similarly, usability has this ubiquity throughout the life-cycle of software. The fastest, most secure, most scalable software can end up in the trash because it misses the most important success criteria for any program in the universe - user acceptance. Software architecture profoundly impacts usability. Usability profoundly impacts acceptance. Though architects may not choose app colors, error messages, and device layout, they certainly make choices that enable or constrain designers and the options they might employ. Like security is everyone's responsibility, so is usability. Inclusive design, on the other hand isn't only about usability; it's about recognizing that your user base changes as their social and environmental contexts change. If your user is standing in the sun, waiting for a train in the snow, holding a baby, riding a bus, visiting a library or watching the big game in a sports bar, applications can account for the one type of user given a certain context looks and acts like another type of user. Inclusive design helps developers understand these contexts and apply them to the implementation of their software for to add more modalities, flexibility in workflows, and intentional tolerance for user mistakes.

I wanted to reply one quick thing to John about the word "design". I did not make up the term Inclusive Design, and I understand the word design has a meaning to developers and designers. But I can't change it because it's the real name of the approach. I added a lot of context in the description that I hope will make it clear to developers that this is for developers and not designers (designers would likely appreciate the content). And this is about using our development decisions to make the design better. I hope this makes sense.

Michael, thank you for your comments! I have extended "Talk Description" field with more details, hope it is good for you now. Please feel free to ask any additional questions or supply more comments. Thank you!

Dmitriy - I’ve personally learned quite a lot from such talks over the years at SATURN in the form of experience reports, keynotes and panels. This topic continues to be of interest to me, and I feel it would be the audience as well.

That being said, your submission is broad, which is good. But then it lacks the specifics that highlight how this talk is 1) different than what was presented before at SATURN and 2) applicable outside of your context.

Given this is only 30-min experience report, I would have preferred to see a focus one component such as creating “internal Architectural Methodology vNext initiative as gravity point for community members” or “assessments and internal educational programs” for growing architects within. talk.title: Concourse : Fly the Friendly CI
talk.description:
Continuous Deployment and Continous Integration are important aspects in modern software development lifecycle, however it is notoriously hard to scale your CI/CD efforts and resources. 

Concourse CI is a Simple, Scalable, and Open Source CI system which aims to solve some of the common struggles teams face when scaling CI for large agile teams deploying to multi-cloud infrastructures. This talk will deep dive into Concourse’s internal workings, and how it can help solve  a range of real world problems and use cases involved in CD/CI testing.
talk.abstract: A deep dive into Concourse’s internal workings, and how it can help solve  a range of real world problems and use cases involved in CD/CI testing.
talk.talk_format: Tech Talks and Tech Tutorials (30 or 90 minutes - please specify the exact time in the Notes section)

ratings.comments:
This seems like a vendor talk.

That being said, the Mesosphere talk last year was also a vendor talk and was pretty good.  I think the difference was that the Mesosphere talk had obvious application beyond Mesosphere and discussed general concepts of container management systems using Mesosphere as the motivating example.

The addition of a compare and contrast in the abstract makes me think this is more about the tool than it is about build automation architecture.
Bottom line he is focusing on scaling CI for large agile teams. So maybe if that leads the talk as a means rather than giving a tutorial on Concourse the talk can be more relevant.
Seems too focused on a single tool.

More on the negative side. Relevant, but a deep dive in 15 minutes does not work. He has also another proposal that looked better prepared.

Einar

feedback.body:
Hi Topher. Thanks for the proposal. I am familiar with the challenges you describe, but I find it hard to understand how a deep dive is possible in 15 minutes. Can you please give me an update of the main takeaways.

Kind regards
Einar

Hi Topher. Thanks for the proposal. I am familiar with the challenges you describe, but I find it hard to understand how a deep dive is possible in 15 minutes. Can you please give me an update of the main takeaways.

Kind regards
Einar

Hey Einar,

Sorry, it looks like PaperCall mis-configured the form to select a 15 minute talk and I was blindly trusting it. This session is typically around 30-35 minutes with 10-15 minutes for questions. 

The intent is to cover Concourse CI and how it compares to existing CI tools like Jenkins, Circle CI, Travis, etc, and show some practical examples of how Concourse can be used in a real-world scenario. The audience will learn about CI and CD best practices, and how Concourse is a good tool to apply those best practices to test and deliver software.

Hope that clears things up!
Thanks
-Topher

Ahh, I figured out the problem; PaperCall mapped their "formats" to yours and what was listed as "Talk - (~30-45 minutes)" submitted as "DEV@SATURN Talk ". I changed it to the format "Other" and that made it "Tech Talks and Tech Tutorials (30 or 90 minutes)"

Hi Topher,

Thanks for your submission.  CI and build pipeline design is certainly an important issue, especially with more and more teams moving to distributed systems such as microservices.  I think this topic could be very relevant to the SATURN audience but I worry that the lessons and analysis may be too tied to the specific tool you mentioned, Concourse CI.

How much of the content in the proposed talk is specific to Concourse CI vs. information that _could_ be applied in other areas but Concourse CI is just the example to show how it works?  Is the purpose of diving into the internal workings of Concourse CI so people can use it better or is there a broader lesson that can be extracted by exploring the internal workings even if I'm not a Concourse CI user?

Regards,

Michael

Hey Michael,

Definitely a valid point; Typically I split the time about 50/50 between covering general topics and covering how concourse specifically helps as a solution. Generally I cover the internals to illustrate why Concourse is a good solution for a specific case within CI/CD, but I can also move more towards a generalist CI/CD strategy talk where Concourse is simple an illustration of a solution to a specific problem.

A specific example I cover is how testing commits to various microservice repos can be integrated together into a pipeline that eventually deploys software externally, and I show an example Concourse pipeline that illustrates this. I can definitely expand more on the former, and provide a good CI/CD strategy overview in the context of distributed systems, microservices, and container orchestration.


Thanks for your feedback! I'm loving that open communication is part of your CFP process!

Cheers,
Topher

talk.title: Developing a High Performance Security Focussed Agile Team
talk.description:
Quality (security included) does not have to be neglected when you're planning, building and running a high performance development team.

Kim will set the stage with how and why Agile Development Teams fail, explained with a familiar anecdote taken from his new book "Holistic Info-Sec for Web Developers", coupled with how you can change this.

Kim will then discuss and demo a set of light weight processes, practises and tools, that when combined have proven their value in:

1. Aiding high throughput (reducing time to market)
2. Significantly increasing quality (finding and removing bugs)
3. Without descoping

and all while reducing total project cost (fact).
If this sounds like breaking the laws of physics, or to good to be true, then this workshop is for you.

Kim will finish off with the habits of top developers and how we can make them part of our lives.
talk.notes:
This is a workshop requiring some attendee setup. Further details provided upon acceptance.

## Workings

### Provide brief context of the following to set the stage:

* [30,000' View](https://leanpub.com/holistic-infosec-for-web-developers/read#starting-with-the-30000-foot-view)
* [10,000' View](https://leanpub.com/holistic-infosec-for-web-developers/read#10000-foot-view-and-lower)
* [Tooling](https://leanpub.com/holistic-infosec-for-web-developers/read#tooling-setup)
* [Process and Practises](https://leanpub.com/holistic-infosec-for-web-developers/read#process-and-practises)
* [Physical](https://leanpub.com/holistic-infosec-for-web-developers/read#physical)
* [People](https://leanpub.com/holistic-infosec-for-web-developers/read#people)

### Step (1)

Discuss how and why development teams fail explained with a familiar anecdote, along with how you can change this (Essentials for Creating and Maintaining a High Performance Development Team), taken from: [https://leanpub.com/holistic-infosec-for-web-developers/read#leanpub-auto-essentials-for-creating-and-maintaining-a-high-performance-development-team](https://leanpub.com/holistic-infosec-for-web-developers/read#leanpub-auto-essentials-for-creating-and-maintaining-a-high-performance-development-team)

### Step (2)

Within every Sprint:

* Cheapest Place to Deal with Defects
* Establish Security Champion (must be within team, not external)
* Along with Test Conditions, create Evil Test Conditions -> basis for your "Security Focussed TDD" -> get these into your CI.
* Hand-crafted Penetration Testing. Let Security Champion lead the way and monitor developers doing this.
* Pair Programming (needs to become part of your culture)
* Code Review (incl automation)
* Linting, static and dynamic analysis
* Static Type Checking
* Consuming free and open source (don't need to stop doing this, address the issue, processes, practises and tooling to mitigate the issue)
* Security Regression Testing (hands on: [https://github.com/binarymist/NodeGoat/wiki/Security-Regression-Testing-with-Zap-API](https://github.com/binarymist/NodeGoat/wiki/Security-Regression-Testing-with-Zap-API)). [Short video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DrwXUOJWMoo&feature=youtu.be) of how this works

### Step (3) Forming Habits and Sharpening Skills

Quality does not have to be neglected when you're planning, building & running a high performance development team.

Kim will set the stage with how and why Agile Development Teams fail, explained with a familiar anecdote, & how you can change this.

ratings.comments: I think the 30 min report is a more suitable format.

This 90 minute participatory session proposes to focus on how agile teams can succeed in quality, especially security, and achieve success.

I have several concerns with this submission:
1) It is not clear what is the participatory aspect of this submission, it reads more like a 90 minute lecture, despite the link to the security regression testing aspect
2) The more interesting part of the talk is the achieving security aspect, however, that is more like a laundry list. 
3) What is the difference of this talk from the other 30 minute one submitted (Secrets of a high performance security focussed Agile Team)?

And lastly, while I appreciated the external links, the author assumes the reviewers will understand what he has in mind from all that information. 

I would strongly recommend to scope this down. Incorporating security focused tasks into any development cycle is a challenge on its own without all the bells and whistles of high performance teams, agile, etc.
Relevant, but as it stand I am at a no-go. Seams to be a bit too fluffy in its structure.

feedback.body:
Hi Kim, thank you for your contribution. Aiming at a 90 minutes talk, I find the description a bit vague. Can you give an outline of how the time is intended spent and how the attendants are intended to contribute. 

Thanks

Have updated the Notes. The largest section is the hands on security regression testing, as attendees are getting a lot out of this. Step 2 is quite similar to this workshop: https://blog.binarymist.net/presentations-publications/#security-regression-testing-with-zapapi-and-nodegoat-nodeconf-eu

Let me know if this needs any more clarification?

Thanks.

Hi Kim,

As written on your other similar proposal, please clarify which format you think works best for your material. The double proposals leave it up to us to judge what is the best way to get your message across, which may or may not work in your benefit.

I like the building a team aspect of your talk, architects often double as leads in one way or another, with or without reporting line responsibility. It seems that you have delivered or intend to deliver this material at developer oriented conferences. We usually see some (lead) developers at SATURN, but please clarify whom your presentation will work for or how it will work for different groups.

Your outline confuses as it is up-high (team-building) and down in the details (hands-on penetration testing). Now having read both proposals, I'd recommend you to update the 30 min session to a focussed talk with a clear value proposition for architects and lead-developers. Dropping more technical material. Think about your audience and what they need, looking at previous SATURN conference programs gives you an idea of what the reviewers think our audience likes.

Good luck with generating publicity around your book!
Thijmen

This submission is a tutorial or workshop. "Secrets of a High Performance Security Focussed Agile Team" is a 25-30 minute presentation.

Both of the two submissions work well, it depends mostly on how much time you can allow. The presentation is not hands on, where as the workshop is. Many people find that they learn better if they actually play with the tools. Playing with the tools is what happens in This workshop. The workshop will work well if we can get the VM I have to attendees before the workshop. Attendees need to have this setup and runable before the workshop, otherwise it usually takes up to much time during the workshop. If we can get a network share setup that attendees can download the VM, and follow the directions I provide before the workshop then it usually works well. Also having a box of NTFS formatted 16GB USB sticks loaded with my VM, that can be handed out on and/or during the conference or even in the workshop, has worked well as a backup plan.

This submission can also be run as a tutorial, which takes less time, due to the non hands on nature, no one has to set anything up other than myself. If run as a tutorial, I just run through the tooling parts as a workshop myself. This way attendees get more of an idea how things fit together than they would if it was just the short presentation.

Numbers also play a part in what works best. If a large number of people wish to attend, then the presentation works best. If over 20 - 30 developers attend, then usually the workshop turns into more of a tutorial, unless, we are really organised and attendees are fully setup before the tutorial/workshop. I have 4 USB  sticks that I can pass around during the workshop, but this only works if there are 20 or less developers in the class.

So in summary, the workshop offers the most, but only if you can support the facilities required and both of us provide excellent comms to people wishing to attend the workshop in the weeks and days leading up to it. My preference is the presentation, as it is less work, but it's your call, I'm happy to run either.

I have run quite a few training's similar to this before:

NodeConfEU (https://blog.binarymist.net/presentations-publications/#security-regression-testing-with-zapapi-and-nodegoat-nodeconf-eu) was a similar workshop (45 people in the class), that may have ended up more of a tutorial, but didn't as we had a box of USB sticks loaded and a network share and had good comms with the attendees before the session.

DevSecCon (https://blog.binarymist.net/presentations-publications/#devseccon-asia-2017-developing-a-high-performance-security-focussed-agile-team-2-hour-workshop) is aiming to host a similar workshop.


Yes, developers/engineers generally get a lot out of this. For me, I generally try not to differentiate to much between devs and architects. An excellent architect should still have their hands on the tools, it's just that they are also expected to be in a lot of other places at the same time. For the architects with less hands on involvement, the tutorial or even presentation style may be best suited to them. In saying that though, if everyone is setup before the workshop, then I can usually hold hands fairly firmly through the hands on content.

The content, whether hands on or not, in many cases is quite eye opening, so there are good take aways for all. My last presentation at AgileNZ (https://blog.binarymist.net/presentations-publications/#agilenz2016-agile-security-for-web-developers-50-minute-presentation) which was mostly targeted toward developers, was still well received by the audience which were mostly Product Owners, Managers and Architects. The AgileNZ presentation had quite a bit of the same content as what I've submitted here.


The high and low level together is what my book series addresses and encourages development teams (PO's, Managers, Architects, Engineers) to grasp and understand. First chapter being 30'000 foot view, which leads into 10,000 foot view, then into some fairly detailed asset identification, risk identification, countermeasure identification, etc... based on Bruce Schneier's Sensible Securitty Model (SSM). The content teaches all people involved in the process of building technical solutions to think outside of their tunnel vision. Architects to think about low level details and Engineers to think holistically, hence the title: "Holistic Info-Sec for Web Developer".

I'm not sure exactly what you mean by clear value proposition? Does the following not provide this:
"have proven their value in:
(1) Aiding high throughput (reducing time to market)
(2) Significantly increasing quality (finding and removing bugs)
(3) Without descoping
and all while reducing total project cost (fact)"


I'd be happy for some assistance to formulate this better for SATURN if you would be keen to help?


Hope that has clarified most of it?
Thanks.

Hi Kim, thank you for the clarification! As we have well over a 100 proposals to review until Friday, I cannot offer any further help right now. Stay tuned, other reviewers may chime in to help them form an opinion. /Thijmen

ratings.comments: I'm open to the idea of dojos but there's nothing in the submission indicating the author has an insight about how to apply it to Saturn-y topics.

Not enough information to risk a 90 minute slot.

Learning objectives are unclear for a DEV@ slot.

Other than a fantastic metaphor, I'm left to my imagination as to what will be covered during this talk.  Though if it lives up to my imagination it probably _would_ be great.  My review is based on the abstract as it stands currently.

Being a blackbelt Karateka, I find this use of the term Dojo interesting, but also a bit offending. You practice for years (takes you at least 5 years to earn a black belt), and suddenly a the concept of Dojo should help programmers improve.
A Dojo is a place where
- you hone your skills and mind under the supervision of a sensei (read master)
- you train hard and you seek insight and understanding as the foundation of your training and practice.

In deep doubt if the concept of Dojo is applicable ...

Creating and running dojos can be a fun session at SATURN and a skill/experience the attendees might want to get experience with. Hi Jorn,  I can run this at 15 minutes as well as at 45-60.  In the past, I have delivered it at 45 minutes.  

I believe I submitted this talk at 15 minutes as my other submissions were longer and more directly oriented around what I expect to be more interesting for attendees.

Hi Joel,

Could you expand on your abstract a bit more?  What goes on in the dojo?  In what situations is the dojo approach appropriate to use?

Regards,

Michael

Hi Michael,
    Sure thing.  In the dojos I have setup / ran, teams are building their products while learning new skills and directly applying them to what they are building.  To give you an example, the last team I was with was building an OAuth service to be used by multiple front-ends.  So they were learning OAuth, along with microservices (Spring Boot in this case), while building with drone / gradle, deploying via kubernetes...all done test driven.  We were doing this in the frame of building their product.  For the majority of the people - it was two teams, about a total of 10 developers - these were new skills. So instead of reading a site and trying to apply something or take a course in one topic, we sat and worked directly with teams on how to build 'the right product, the right way.'  Other teams have learned Java (coming from mainframe), mobile development, etc.  I have even ran these with non-technical teams like L&D or marketing.

So what goes on?  Learning in the context of building your stuff.

I am of course biased to a dojo approach - I like the idea of whole teams learning together in their context.  I would offer up that if you just have a single skill that needs to be amplified, a dojo wouldn't be right.  For example, if you just need to understand kafka - then yeah, a dojo might be overkill.  

Thanks for the feedback.

Best,
Joel

The cynical part of me wonders if the author has a generally applicable tech and if the talk is accepted will figure out how to target it at the conference attendees.  And the really cynical part of me wonders if we'd get just the generic talk.

talk.title: Fixing Agile
talk.description:
Agile is broken.  The SEI should know this and lead a campaign to fix it.

Agilists believe that requirements “emerge” during iterative development.  They also believe that Big Requirements Up Front (BRUF) is an Agile anti-pattern.  While BRUF may be a poor strategy for gathering functional requirements, it is the best strategy for identifying quality goals.

Most functional requirements may eventually emerge because of clearer customer understanding.  Unfortunately, most quality goals will not and those that do are unlikely to emerge early.

Internal quality goals such as code understandability and testability, will never emerge from domain understanding.  Some high-profile external goals such as safety, security, and privacy may emerge, but at unpredictable times.  Others, such as ease of use, reliability, and responsiveness, will emerge if there are gross quality failures.  A focus on functionality will delay emergence of most quality goals.

In all cases, waiting for quality goal emergence is a poor idea and unnecessary.  Waiting results in the accumulation of sizable technical debt during early iterations.  Debt piles up because quality support functions, such as exception handlers, are missing everywhere.

Use of a comprehensive quality model enables quality goals to be identified early.  It also enables the early specification of both quality achievement and quality verification strategies.  Such a quality model is freely available at www.quality-aware.com/q-a-daves-stuff.php.  The steps to fix Agile and any other incremental development process can be found at www.quality-aware.com.

SEI publications state that understanding quality goals is an important prerequisite to good architectural decisions.  This suggests that most quality goals should be identified early.  This conflicts with stated Agile beliefs and current Agile practice.  The SEI has been silent on this conflict.  It is time to speak up and campaign for Quality-Aware Agile.

This presentation will
•	Explore current quality practices with attendees
•	Describe why Agile and every incremental development process is broken
•	Describe the added tasks of Quality-Aware development
•	Simulate a review and tailoring of the LiteRM quality model in an inspection overview format
•	Explore objections to using these proposals with attendees
talk.notes: None
talk.abstract: Agilists believe that Big Requirements Up Front is an Agile anti-pattern.  While BRUF may be a poor strategy for gathering functional requirements, it is the best strategy for identifying quality goals.  Agile should incorporate early identification of quality goals to avoid sizable technical debt.

ratings.comments:
Pros - very provocative title and thesis likely to garner a large opinionated audience and lively debate which might lead to narrower and more defensible claims by the submitter including a more nuanced view of when his approach is most appropriate and provides the most value

Cons - while quality attributes and nonfunctional requirements are a big driver of architecture and therefore a fundamental and critical phase of the architecture process, the SATURN audience is typically (unfortunately IMHO) more focused on architectural design, implementation, evaluation etc. treating  the architecturally significant requirements as a given

BTW - software development methodology in general is a field devoid of controlled experiments and refutation of theories based on rigorous statistical analysis of empirical observations and evidence so holding a SATURN submitter to that standard seems a little unfair ;)

While I agree that agile software development methodologies can at times impose challenges in focusing on architecturally significant requirements, I do not think it is grounded to claim agile is broken here is how to fix it without proof. Without solid factual data this talk reads more like a whining pitch about agile.
Highly doubtful. 90 minutes on this topic is too long in my opinion. If he can do it in 30 minutes, its a yes from my side.

While there is some hyperbole in the talk, it seems like a relevant topic for a 30 minute session.  This speaker gave a talk on similar topic at SATURN 2015: https://saturn2015.sched.com/event/2Nys/understanding-quality-goals

As a 90 minute talk I'm less sure.  It would be nice to see more about what the speaker plans to do with the time.

talk.title: Is Your Project in Trouble on System Performance?
talk.description:
Performance is one of the critical architecture quality attributes and it is a non-functional requirement that is used as an acceptance criteria for almost every project / system. Performance also impacts the usability and user adoption rate after the system goes live. However, performance issues usually show up during the later phases of the project or during system implementation such as Load / Stress Test and / or User Acceptance Test (UAT) when data volume scales up. The probable cause is a lack of non-functional requirements on performance at an early stage of the architectural design. This presentation is to conceive and show how to salvage a troubled project with performance issues that focuses on performance and storage trade-offs, and how Architecture Analysis Tradeoff Method (ATAM) is used to leverage the performance and storage trade-offs. The specific tailored solution I wanted to share is to move data aggregation and sorting from backend database to Solr or Elasticsearch as an indexing service so that data aggregation and sorting can be indexed ahead of time and be accessed over http through query parameters. I will also discuss performance concerns from end-to-end in systems the deal with heavy data aggregation and sorting using real-world implementation examples. Perspectives on how to address performance concerns and turn around a troubled project in a very short period of time will also be elaborated.

Introduction and Architecture Quality Attributes (5 minutes) 
Performance and Storage Trade-offs by example (15 minutes) 
Architectural Dynamics, Challenges, and Impacts (5 minutes) 
Q&A (5 minutes)
talk.notes:
The take away for this presentation will be the practical techniques to salvage projects with severe system performance issues. This presentation is based on my real-world experiences in salvaging two multiple-million dollar projects in a very short period. Neither project conducted architecture quality attributes workshop (QAW). The performance issues were so severe that the projects were subject to be cancelled. The root of causes were extensive data aggregation with heavy computation and sorting on a low-end databases. One of the two projects simply tried to reuse a simple mobile application architecture with 2 search criteria and less than 100 thousand records on a PostgreSQL to a full blown application with 100 million records with over 20 search criteria. When performance issues appeared at UAT, $2 million dollars were already invested in the project. I will present a quick turnaround options including tailored solutions ranging from increasing hardware / network capacity, database tuning / query optimization, API optimization, to the implementation of Solr or Elasticsearch to address the performance issue. The examples I will use in the presentation will be performance and storage trade-offs that leverage the Solr or Elasticsearch as an indexing service so that data aggregation and sorting can be indexed ahead of time. The architectural dynamics, challenges, and impacts such as Solr indexing time impact to the existing ETL process and PaaS issues will also be presented. The practical knowledge of this presentation will benefit architects and business decision makers to understand the important of Architecture Quality Attributes and how to address performance issues with tailored solutions.

I think the presentation belongs to Track 3: Other topics interest - Addressing quality attribute concerns, such as performance, availability, usability, security, and interoperability
talk.abstract: Why do so many projects have system performance issues at a later stage of implementation? Are projects with severe performance issues salvageable? ratings.comments: Maybe he does a great talk, but the way it's written doesn't inspire confidence.  I do like the examples.

feedback.body:
Summary:
The talk reminds the audience of the importance of designing for key quality attributes based on the author’s industry experience. The author applies accepted practices (for example, QAW, ATAM, UAT) during a turn-around of stranded projects. Finally, the talk would give practical guidance on the suitability of various database technologies for two projects the author worked on.

The good and to improve:
The author correctly points out the importance of designing for important quality attributes up-front and gives concrete examples of the potential cost of failing to do so. While a real world story could engage the audience, we should expect most SATURN attendees to already be aware of these risks.

Concrete guidance on dealing with performance issues could be of interest to the SATURN community. The proposal does not tell us how the ‘tailored solutions’ used may generalise to other software systems that the audience works on. I would like to see some hints about what classes of systems or problems could benefit from the solutions.

Idea:
A talk outline with rough timing could help the reviewers better judge the focus of the talk. Please also elaborate your idea on how your talk may impact the work/actions of others. You could also look at this blog for a checklist: https://insights.sei.cmu.edu/saturn/2016/11/seven-proposal-writing.html

Excellent feedback! The specific tailored solution I wanted to share is to move data aggregation and sorting from backed end database to Solr or Elasticsearch as an indexing service so that data aggregation and sorting can be indexed ahead of time and be access over http through query parameters. This tailored solution is a trade-off between performance and storage in addition to other traditional performance turning approaches. 

The talk outline with rough timing is as follows - 
Introduction, background, and problem statement (5 minutes)
The Importance of Designing for Key Architecture Quality Attributes (5 minutes)  
Performance and Storage Trade-offs by example (10 minutes)
Architectural Dynamics, Challenges, and Impacts on Performance (5 minutes)
Q&A (5 minutes)

Hi Charles, I understood it should be possible to amend your submission even now that the deadline passed.
