Hello Thilmen, Thanks for the feedback. I updated my Talk Description as follows, but was not able to edit the original description.  Any help I can get from you to revise the original submission?
---------
Performance is one of the critical architecture quality attributes. The performance Service Level Agreement (SLA) is a non-functional requirement that is used as an acceptance criteria for almost every project / system. Performance SLA also impacts the usability and user adoption rate after the system goes live. However, performance issues usually show up during the later phases of the project or during system implementation such as Load / Stress Test and / or User Acceptance Test (UAT) when data volume scales up. The probable cause is a lack of defined architecture quality attributes and vague non-functional requirements on performance at the early stage of the project such as architectural design. This presentation is to conceive and show how to salvage a troubled project with performance SLA issues that focuses on performance and storage trade-offs, and how Architecture Analysis Tradeoff Method (ATAM) is used to leverage the performance and storage trade-offs. The specific tailored solution I wanted to share is to move data aggregation and sorting from backed end database to Solr or Elasticsearch as an indexing service so that data aggregation and sorting can be indexed ahead of time and be access over http through query parameters. I will also discuss detailed issue resolution approaches to address performance concerns from end-to-end, real-world implementation on performance and storage trade-offs to turn the project around in a very short period of time to meet the performance SLA.

Introduction and Architecture Quality Attributes? (5 minutes)
Performance and Storage Trade-offs by example (15 minutes)
Architectural Dynamics, Challenges, and Impacts (5 minutes)
Q&A (5 minutes)
--------

Hi Thilmen, please discard my prior feedback / comment. I was able to update the Talk Description based on your feedback.

Thanks for your feedback.

Charles

Hi Charles,

I have a few suggestions/comments: 

1. I think the talk description uses the term SLA inaccurately. SLA is a document that may specify perfomance requirements, among other things. I'd argue that the majority of software systems out there do not have such a document in effect. So, saying "The performance Service Level Agreement (SLA) is a non-functional requirement that is used as an acceptance criteria for almost every project / system" is an overstatement to me. But if you drop the term "Service Level Agreement (SLA)", the sentence sounds quite valid. 

2. Likewise, the SLA document doesn't impact usability. It's performance that affects usability. 

3. The talk description uses quite some space to discuss the general importance of performance as a quality attribute requirement. I believe that's not the focus of the talk, but as is the description becomes less interesting, because many SATURN attendees are well aware that performance requirements are important. The title and description could be more specific and clearly indicate what kind of performance optimization is discussed. In other words, I suggest you say in the title and abstract what specific kind of performance solution you'll present. 

4. You say "The probable cause is a lack of defined architecture quality attributes and vague non-functional requirements on performance at the early stage of the project such as architectural design." It's not clear to me what is "defined architecture quality attributes" versus " non-functional requirements on performance."  Also, I think it would make more sense to say "at an early stage of the architectural design" instead of "at the early stage of the project such as architectural design."

5. The phrase "I will also discuss detailed issue resolution approaches to address performance concerns from end-to-end"  sounds very general and hence too ambitious. Maybe you should be more specific, such as "... performance concerns from end-to-end in systems that deal with text search on indexed data sets. 

6. The term "storage trade-offs" is not clear. Is is about tradeoffs regarding the choice of infrastructure used for persisting data? Maybe RDBMS vs NoSQL databases? Maybe tradeoffs related to Lucene indexing options? 

7. SATURN attendees are interested in technologies, tools, frameworks that have been used successfully. So, in an unbiased fashion, you could try to mention tools such as profilers and performance monitors that you have used. Learning about the experience of others with such tools may raise the interest in your talk. 

Typos:

- "sorting from back**end database to Solr "

- "and be access*ed* over http"

I'm drawn to this talk because of the specifics of the case studies as described in the Notes section.  I like talks that have a clear example from which a clear lesson can be taken away.  It works well in 30-minute conference slots.

But, and I'm slightly embarrassed to admit how I'm jumping to conclusions, I'm concerned that the way the author has written the descriptions (ie, a big paragraph of "we will discuss X, Y, and Z" without a clear takeaway message) will translate into clear value for the audience.  Many authors provide an outline of the talk or topics, which makes it clear how they are organizing their thoughts and linearizing the knowledge.

Hi Paulo, thanks for the detailed feedback. I updated the "Talk Description" to reflect your comments and suggestions. Regarding performance / storage trade-offs, my intent is to discuss the details via several examples since there are pros and cons for each technology. Tailor the solution to the business needs to turn the troubled project around successfully is something I would like share with the audience. 

Again, Thanks
Charles

I also updated the Talk Description section to be more descriptive on the take away. The outline of talks is at the end of the Talk Description section. 

Thanks
Charles

talk.title: Learning Roadmap for Newbie Architects
talk.description:
If you are new to the role of software architect or aspiring to become one, this session will provide you a learning roadmap to acquire the various skills needed to succeed, as well as how to continuously upgrade your knowledge, this is the session for you.

Based on my years of experience as application / solution / enterprise architect, as well as coaching and mentoring new architects in many of my client organizations, I would suggest the list of technical and non-technical skills the attendees should have, and how to go about acquiring those skills, such as:

* familiarity with important terminology and various streams in software architecture (such as application, integration, infrastructure, security, information, solution, enterprise)
* design principles and patterns, architecture patterns
* methodologies for architecture, design, and software development
* major technology areas and frameworks
* trends and emerging areas of interests
* compliance and governance areas
* soft skills
talk.notes:

feedback.body: Thanks Pradyumn for submitting an interesting topic. Would you be providing details from your vast experience to cover the mental thinking that needs to change from being a Developer? ie What is it that an Architect need to do differently from a Developer or a Dev Lead? How to achieve that transition. I think that would be useful for the audience as well.

Yes, I would cover that too. Mindset change is very important. Things like business focus, the big picture, collaboration, conflict resolution, learning, sharing cannot be ignored for a successful transition.  And I intend to cover such aspects also.

Thank you for your submission. I have a few suggestions/comments: 

1. Today Software Architecture is taught at many undergrad and graduate academic programs in the US and abroad. Also, there are many professional training classes available. Some are vendor agnostic (such as the SEI courses), others are offered by vendors, such as Microsoft and Oracle. In your presentation, do you consider taking classes on software architecture an effective possible step in the roadmap? 

2. The software architect should also have a clear understanding of quality attributes, such as modifiability, availability, performance, and security. He/she should know how to elicit and document quality attribute requirements, because these requirements are the most important architecture drivers. 

3. The architect should also understand that architecture consists of multiple structures, which are documented in multiple views. He/she should know how to communicate the multi-view architecture effectively. Many times this communication involves diagrams, so the architect should know UML or know how to create and use an informal diagram notation consistently. 

4. A question that could be discussed in your presentation: is there value in pursuing one of the different available software architecture certifications? 

5. The architect should also know how to create, document, and evaluate an architecture. 

6. Years ago people at the SEI software architecture group engaged in a discussion about the duties, skills and knowledge of an architect. One of the results of that discussion is on [this web page](https://www.sei.cmu.edu/architecture/research/previousresearch/duties.cfm). It might have useful information for your presentation. 

7. In the notes section, consider including an outline of your talk, even if it’s only tentative.

8. It would be interesting to see a discussion of what has changed in recent years in the role of architect in the "digital era", the era of microservices, containers, and agile development.

talk.title: New connectivity feature for IoT: API with multi-network SIM cards
talk.description: An implicit goal of developing applications is to increase the quality of life, or the general well-being of individuals and society as a whole. In light of this a, new paradigm of the real-time communication between things has emerged, in which the quality of life of citizens in dense urban environments is increased through the use big data and cloud technology. The rapidly changing social and environmental order is becoming more complex as resources grow scarcer and populations increase, it requires just one technical integration point in IoT, which will provide technological fluency in the use big data for public benefit. The proposal idea is the “wherever SIM” that provides the network coverage wherever devices may roam, has its own independent cloud based network, extremely scalable and global. SIM cards and endpoints can be easily managed in real-time via the intuitive user-interface or directly from the customer’s software application via an easy-to-integrate API for SIM cards. Key features, development and implementation stages, as well as use cases and code demonstration will be discussed.

Dear George, thank you for your feedback! 

I would like to add some comments that in reality IoT solves the same problem for communication points as software architecture tries to solve for many years - distributed computing. Different nodes on different machines try to communicate with each other as well different devices and controllers do. 
These IoT devices can certainly connect through a lot of different ways, but in this talk I focus on cellular connectivity. Obviously, other receptions are always limited to the access point, and also dependent on network and device configurations. Cellular has reception everywhere without any maintenance effort from the customer side, so with telecom access a large-scale investigation is possible. Given the ubiquity of sim based IoT devices, cellular solutions can achieve an unbelievable level of coverage in both space and time for observing any events.
If we take IoT and wanna use it in a large scale for example in agriculture industry in Africa, we have to built a suitable large architecture. As low-energy network does not exist there and can provide connectivity only on one site, so the communication with the combine on the field will be always insecure. Even SMS can play a role as an intermediate solution and help with device distribution or middleware. GSM network always can be used, even if internet is not available, which makes it reliable and persistent channel for IoT connectivity.
In my talk I include not only an agriculture, but also e-health, logistic and alarm system cases, with journey map and code demonstration.

Cheers, Karina

talk.title: Qualities are Very Complex
talk.description:
At the beginning of a software project, you should identify likely project risks.  Quality goals such as those for safety and security may be among them.  These goals must be defined, achieved, and verified.  We show that current quality models, such as ISO 25010, are simplistic and then describe a quality model of sufficient complexity.

We highlight the features of a quality knowledge base that outlines over 60 quality attributes, their support and conflict relationships, and their tactics for goal definition, achievement, and verification.  This knowledge base is freely available and enables you to identify your quality goals and strategies at the beginning of a project.  If you don’t use it, you may waste time and increase project risk.

feedback.body:
Hi David,

Thank-you for your submission.  I'm very interested in the topic of software quality, but I'm sorry to say that I'm finding your description a little perplexing.

The title is confusing me.  My initial thought was that you were saying "Software Quality Attributes Considered Harmful."

However, reading the introduction paragraph makes me think you are actually saying is "Poor Quality is Risky", or perhaps "A Little Quality Model is a Dangerous Thing" because you need one that is big enough to do the job properly.

By "essentially complex" do you mean "necessarily complex"?  i.e.  This is the level of complexity that is needed as a minimum, you cannot go any simpler than this?

When you say "essentially complex" do you actually mean that the model is complex by nature.  Complexity is often seen as a undesirable, , so complex nature could be a bad thing.

Reading on I see that you are presenting a quality knowledge base.  Am I right in thinking that this is the "Essentially complex quality model."  Since you are presenting it, then I assume it must be a good thing.  The title and introduction don't make this clear.

Also, you begin the second paragraph referring to "some at the SEI."  You then refer to "We".  Is the "We" the people at the SEI, or are you referring to the people ClearSpecs Enterprises? 

I hope you can understand my confusion and can help me clarify my understanding.

Regards, 


Ged

Sorry for the confusion. 

I changed the title to "Qualities are Very Complex" because that is my message.  I am using "essential complexity" as Fred Brooks does.  DNA, the London subway, and Einstein's theory of relativity are each more complex than a triangle or benzene molecule.  

"Essential complexity" is neither bad nor good.  It is a scalar characteristic, like weight.  By definition, if I build a model or solve a problem, the essential complexity of the thing being modeled or the problem being solved determines the essential complexity of an accurate model or an effective solution.

While understanding higher levels of essential complexity is very difficult, simplistic understanding can be dangerous.  If the software in a self-driving car is simplistic, people will die needlessly.  

“A Simplistic Quality Model is a Dangerous Thing” because you need one that is big enough to do the job properly. – Yes   Complexity is often seen as undesirable, [just like too much weight], so complex nature could be a bad thing – No [Human intelligence is not a bad thing, but unnecessary complexity is a bad thing.]  Reading on I see that you are presenting a quality knowledge base. Am I right in thinking that this is the “Essentially complex quality model.” – Yes

Here is the rewrite:  Qualities are Very Complex

At the beginning of a project, you should identify likely project risks.  Quality goals may be among them.  These goals must be defined, achieved, and verified.  We show that current quality models are simplistic and then describe a quality model of sufficient complexity.

We highlight the features of a quality knowledge base that outlines over 60 quality attributes, their support and conflict relationships, and their tactics for goal definition, achievement, and verification.  This knowledge base is freely available and enables you to identify your quality goals and strategies at the beginning of a project.  If you don’t use it, you may waste time and increase project risk.

Improvement suggestions much appreciated.  Thanks.

Thanks for the submission. I have a few suggestions from the perspective of a conference participant looking at the conference program:
1) The talk abstract sounds a little vague. Maybe you could say "software project" instead of just project. Maybe say "Quality goals, such as..."
2) It's not clear what you mean by quality models. Examples? 
3) Many software developers simply ignore quality attribute requirements. I think we need techniques that make specification, design, and validation of quality goals simple and practical. IMO, a "quality model of sufficient complexity" doesn't sound very enticing to the agile, framework-oriented developer of today. 

Also, in the notes section, consider including an outline of your talk, even if it’s only tentative.

Hi Paulo:

Great suggestions - see revision.  This talk is meant to fill the 15 min. slots that I thought were described in the CFP, even though this duration is not included in this online system.  I have a pdf of my 12 slides, but there is no provision for uploading files.  If you provide an email address, I will be happy to supply them.

You wrote: "Many software developers simply ignore quality attribute requirements. I think we need techniques that make specification, design, and validation of quality goals simple and practical. IMO, a “quality model of sufficient complexity” doesn’t sound very enticing to the agile, framework-oriented developer of today."

I agree with all but the word "simple".  The set of quality attributes and some individual attributes like safety and security are NOT simple (just like DNA).  Some attributes have entire books written about them. Their specification, design, and verification is NOT simple.

I understand that I am "selling" complexity (reality?), but the earth is not flat and orbits are not circular.  Simplistic models of quality attributes will never produce predictable quality.

As to enticing the Agile crowd, there are many problems.  I have written that "Agile is a Quality Antipattern" and "Fixing Agile".  "Pure" agile is simplistic.  It can work great as long as you ignore quality goals.  These goals don't fit the Agile paradigm because they should be identified and specified early and achieved and verified in every iteration.  In surveys of current Agile practice, over 50% of the responders don't following any coding standards.  These Agile projects build huge quality debt starting from the first increment.  True Agile believers are not my target audience,  Those using Agile, but concerned about quality, are.

profile.name: Shai Yallin
profile.bio: I'm an engineering manager at the Wix Backend Group, where I have introduced and spread the use of the Scala programming language. I have been a TDD advocate for the past 5 years and have introduced TDD to numerous software teams at Wix.com and at other software companies in Israel. I have also lead the development of Wix’s backend platform and numerous products using it.

talk.title: TDD: Cultivating a Beginner's Mind
talk.description:
Even though Agile has been around for more than 15 years, many software organizations still practice Big Design Up Front. A lot of focus is put on the *initial development* aspect, before the first delivery, and little attention is given to the *maintenance phase* of the software system. With more and more organizations shifting to SaaS models, creating long-lived Internet systems that aren’t forgiving to downtimes or cumbersome data migrations, maintenance becomes much more important and critical to the overall design of the system than the initial development.

Agile offers a different, *Emergent* method to design software, with small iterations that, when combined with continuous delivery and learning, results in a design that’s much more adaptive to changing requirements. Taken to the extreme, we shorten the initial development phase to a minimum and focus mostly on iterative maintenance steps. 

However, the conditions required to facilitate Emergent Design require that the development team refrain from over-engineering and YAGNI violations - two problems that are prevalent in the software industry, especially with less-experienced engineers. Outside-In Development is a methodology that helps us focus on the Semantics rather the Mechanics of our software, protect us from YAGNI violations, and thus facilitate Emergent Design. Practicing TDD helps us implement this methodology in the scope of a commercial software project, by helping us cultivate a Beginner’s Mind towards software design.
talk.notes:
I will start by describing the gap between how engineers usually view software design and how Internet-scale systems actually evolves. I will then make the point that software isn’t like bridges, cars or other “classical” engineering projects. I will use the biological analogy, talking about software as a garden and how we always build on existing system state, and how software engineering is an ongoing, evolving effort. I will claim that a paradigm shift is needed towards wide adoption of Emergent Design.

Next, I will explain why traditional software engineering training is deleterious to this paradigm shift, with people learning to think about static, rather than evolving, software design, and are taught more about the mechanics of software (design patterns, technology) and less about the semantics (creating the right abstractions). I will discuss Outside-In Development and explain how it helps stick to the YAGNI principle, and how this facilitates Emergent Design. I will explain that it’s hard to adopt outside-in due to the way engineers are trained and how cultivating a Beginner’s Mind helps us put aside these problems and achieve outside-in.

Finally, I will explain how practicing TDD helps us cultivate the Beginner’s Mind and facilitate outside-in, with test-first serving as the outside user of a system or subsystem, and how the Refactoring phase of TDD helps design emerge.

### Presentation History:
Initially developed in 2014 as an internal Wix.com tech talk. Presented in:
Reversim Summit Tel Aviv 2015 
Voxxed Days Vilnius 2015 
Clean Code Days Munich 2015 
Continuous Lifecycle London 2016
XP2016 Edinburgh
Testcon Vilnius 2016
talk.abstract: Everyone’s talking about Agile, but most of us actually do Scrumfall. The rise of SaaS systems calls for a paradigm shift in software design. In this talk, I will discuss Emergent Design using TDD as a way around the inherent problems in Big Design Up Front and our education as software engineers.

ratings.comments: The proposal seems solid. My biggest concern is with the matter that Michael raised with Shai--why is this presentation uniquely appropriate for an architecture conference? Shai didn't have a great answer to that. Final decision on this one may depend on the extent to which we want to include general-interest software engineering presentations along with those with a particular focus on architecture.

TDD has been established for a while now, I am not sure what new angle this talk would provide. I would like to see a balance between up-front design and TDD at an architecture conference.

Update: after reading the conversation with the speaker, I understand more and agree with Michael's sentiment. However, I find it disturbing that the speaker uses many terms/acronyms without defining them, also in the 'public' abstract.

Generally I like everything the speaker proposes but the topic seems extremely introductory.  It does not seem like there is anything new here or much that directly relates to software architecture topics.

Update: Given some of the discussions with Shai and the emphasis on design over mechanics I think his has potential to be a good session.

feedback.body:
Hi Shai,

I am a huge supporter of TDD and 100% agree with most everything in your abstract.  With that said, this topic has been around for a while.  What is new your talk compared to the common or prevailing lessons for using and benefits of TDD?  How will you relate TDD directly to software architecture topics (opposed to typical design or programming topics)?

Regards,

Michael

Hi Michael,

Thanks for the feedback. First and foremost, I can't actually promise that anything I say is new to the audience of SATURN, although I have delivered this talk in earlier formats at various European conferences, including XP2016 in Edinburgh earlier this year, and got positive feedback.

One major difference is that I'm talking about Test-Driven *Design* rather than Test-Driven Development. Many talks and books deal with Test-Driven Development, focusing on the "how"s rather than the "why"s - how to write unit tests, for instance, rather than "what's in it for me". My talk, and to a greater extent my epiphany, has to do with our fallacies as software engineers, their origins, and how TDD, by helping us cultivate a beginner's mind, can aid in getting rid or taming these fallacies, which include YAGNI violation, over-engineering, pattern obsession and so on. 

While this talk doesn't relate to software architecture in the common sense (topology, microservices, databasesm etc), it does deal with how adhering to TDD as a methodology is beneficial for software organizations that develop web-scale, long-lived Internet systems, as was our experience at Wix.com.

Shai, Thanks for the update!  Thanks for explaining the nuance -- design over mechanics. TDD is a great way to dive into these topics and I think this would be the right approach for this conference.  Good luck in the review process!

Hi Shai,

I'm particularly interested in your emphasis on addressing the maintenance phase.  Is the approach you are describing something that can be applied to a system that is already in the maintenance phase?

In his book "Working Effectively with Legacy Code" Michael Feather describes a number of techniques for introducing tests to legacy code.  Are you talking about a similar approach here?

Or are you talking about anticipating the needs of maintenance during the initial phases?

Hi Ged,

I'm talking about anticipating the needs of maintenance during the initial phase. Furthermore, I'm claiming that the initial phase in itself is getting way too much attention, whereas the important bit of software development lies in maintenance. Taken to the extreme, an example would be deploying an empty application to production, then starting to add features to it ('Walking Skeleton' in GOOS lingua).

Shai
Hi Shai, from the YouTube video, it looks like a 30-minute talk. Is that correct? Thanks.

Hi Michele,
I'd say 40 minutes, 45 with Q&A. The video is edited a bit, and I was delivering after a sleepless night, which caused me to be really too fast.
Thanks! I'll tag it as 45 for the review committee's consideration. :)

Thank you for your submission. 

I have a few suggestions/comments: 

1. I don't understand what you mean by "more and more organizations shifting to SaaS models" in practice. Do you mean more development organizations are creating their software solutions as SaaS? Is it true for the enterprise? Or do you mean more organizations are using various SaaS solutions, such as dockerhub and github? 

2. I think maintainability is an important quality attribute requirement for software systems in general. If you use patterns and tactics that promote maintainability, I think you are giving attention to the maintenance phase. In the first paragraph, it seems you are saying that BDUF does not focus on maintainability. I don't think that's the problem with BDUF. The problem is that you design beyond what's known at the beginning. If you start coding earlier, initial releases will give you incredible understanding of runtime/maintainability issues that help to drive downstream design in the right direction. 

3. Here's what wikipedia says about Emergent Design: "With emergent design, a development organization starts delivering functionality and lets the design emerge. Development will take a piece of functionality A and implement it using best practices and proper test coverage and then move on to delivering functionality B. Once B is built, or while it is being built, the organization will look at what A and B have in common and refactor out the commonality, allowing the design to emerge. This process continues as the organization continually delivers functionality."
I'm not sure this is your interpretation of emergent design. In any case, it is important to reflect about some points. Is this approach good in all cases? If not, what's the criteria to decide when to use it? Aren't there tradeoffs related to following emergent design? What kinds of design decisions are in the scope of this approach? Does emergent design prevent the use of techniques (such as DDD) that ask you to design beyond the scope of a scrum sprint functionality? 

4. From the perspective of a conference participant looking at the conference program, I think the title+description don't make it clear what the talk is about. The title makes you think it's about TDD. The description may make you think the talk is about Emergent Design and/or the outside-in development approach. 

5. In the notes section, consider including an outline of your talk, even if it’s only tentative.

6. In the description, consider adding what participants will learn, that is, how do they benefit from this talk. 

Typos:

- "Semantics rather *than* the Mechanics"

- "protect*s* us from YAGNI"

- "and thus facilitate*s* Emergent Design"

Hi Paulo,
Re: 1 - I mean that companies start offering their products as SaaS rather than on-premise. I think this also applies to enterprise, yes - if you look at major software companies, such as HPE - who have traditionally been offering on-prem solutions only.

Re: 2 - yes, I agree with what you say. But I think that the mere act of *performing* a BDUF will create a mindset that thinks in terms of a deliverable ("car") rather than an evolvable ("garden").

Re: 3 - note that I'm not referring to scope, or to sprints. I'm referring to letting design emerge rather than forcing a design that stems from the mind of an architect (and not from evidence). What recently became clearer to me is that most of what I say is applicable mainly to Applications, as defined by Lehman (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lehman's_laws_of_software_evolution).

Re: 4 - what I'm trying to say is that TDD is a great way to promote emergent design, by helping the engineer cultivate a beginner's mind. Do you think this is not clear from the title/abstract?

(4) TDD (test-driven development) is a well known Agile practice. Emergent Design is not a familiar term for many. So, IMO one looking at the title can easily think this is a talk about test-driven development--more so, one may think it's about test-driven development for beginners (like the TDD Kata talk by Bob Martin).

feedback.body:
Hi David,

The topic of serverless is going to be hot this year.  Could you provide some additional details for what you plan to cover in this proposed session?  Also, how is this talk going to be different from the other talk you proposed, _Event Driven Application Architectures_?

Michael

Thanks for submitting a very interesting topic.

Details of various providers that support Serverless Architecture and how to chose a specific provider

All the Best!
Hi David, is this a 30- or 90-minute talk? Thanks.

Hi David,
Thank you for the submission. I have a few suggestions/comments: 

1. I fully agree with Yogeshwar. You should also discuss the challenges and drawbacks of serverless architecture. Software architects need to understand the tradeoffs that come with any design decision. A lot of material we see out there about the newest and brightest idea often only emphasize the benefits. Surely serverless is not the best solution for all cases.

2. The term serverless is actually quite broad and poorly defined. For example, [Mike Roberts](https://martinfowler.com/articles/serverless.html) associates serverless to the use of MBaaS (more common), or alternatively richer clients (SPA?) talking to services behind an API gateway. Thus, I hope your talk has a clear description of what a serverless architecture is. A brief definition of serverless in the talk description would also be helpful to correctly set the expectations of participants looking at the conference program.

3. In the notes section, consider including an outline of your talk, even if it’s only tentative.

4. Like Michael, I too see significant overlap with your other submission. Please provide more information on how do they differ.

talk.title: The future of delivery messenger channels with SMS-fallback.
talk.description: Probably everyone remembers earlier days, when SMS was one of the most used means of communication. This times, the dissemination of SMS in private communication is decreasing whereas SMS is still often used for commercial communication especially for one-directional distribution of information from company to customer. In the future, the SMS may also lose this position and then will only serve as fallback. New channels, especially internet-based messengers like Facebook Messenger, WhatsApp or Threema, will become more and more important and will compete with SMS. Instead of sending SMS to customers, companies will start using the same channels for commercial conversation as their customers for private. SMS then will only be used in case an internet-based channel is not available or for time critical services.
talk.abstract: Internet-based messengers like Facebook Messenger, Threema and WhatsApp will more and more compete with SMS in one-directional commercial communication. SMS will then only be used as fallback or in case of time critical services.

ratings.comments: I don't see a good fit for DEV@SATURN. Where is the unique "technique, lesson, or experience" related to SMS that could inspire and relate to the audience in a plenary? Karina mentioned use SMS services during refugee movement... I'd think that theme being the central idea of the talk could be a fit of DEV@SATURN.

Topic could be interesting, but talk abstract and description fail to specify what the talk would be about: they only list status quo of the market and predict a future  - and then end suddenly. How is a prospective attendee supposed to know what (s)he will learn in the session?
Feel this runs at risk of a sales pitch for the author's company, too little information in the submission to judge.

A discussion around performance or availability degradation scenarios is important and interesting. 

As a DEV@ talk, I think this could be interesting.  There could be something longer here, but without more in the abstract I feel it's a bit of a leap of faith.

feedback.body:
Hi Karina,

Thanks for your submission!  Given many of the recent events we've seen with the refugee crisis in Europe I think this is a timely topic for architects to consider.  Not everyone in the world has access to wireless internet and high bandwidth signals all the time.

How much technical detail do you plan to cover in your talk?  What will attendees know or be able to do by the end of your talk?  We have a strong preference at SATURN for talks that explore "how" to do something over "what" something is.

Also, I see that you submitted this talk to the DEV@ track.  I just want to confirm that you know DEV@ talks are a 15 minute time slot on the main stage (200+ people).

Regards,

Michael

Good morning, Michael, once again, 

Yes, you are totally right, we can see a strong increase of customers, who uses SMS services during refugees movements.

As we work very closely with different messenger solutions, their APIs plus also have our own routing system and provide testing and fall back options, I can put lots of technical stuff inside and do it a hands-on technical session for longer than 15 min on how to integrate different solutions together, if you are interested in it. Please let me know which format of this session you would be interested in. 

Regards,
Karina

Summary: 
The talk will shed light on the changing role of SMS in human communications towards a fallback option.

The good and to improve:
The topic is highly current and relevant to the community. I would like to know more about the learnings the audience could take away. What is the idea worth spreading? Why is it relevant for the architecture community.

The proposal does not include a talk outline, and the abstract fails to put its finger on the relevance to development and architecture practice.

Idea:
Please have a look at the proposal writing tips and add a bit more information to enable a more information decision for the reviewers.

profile.name: Rizwan Javaid
profile.bio: Rizwan is a User Experience Designer. He creates intuitive, persuasive, and profitable user experiences for top brands such as PayPal, Allstate, Holland America, and Riverbed. He loves sharing his passion for sketching at meetups and conferences. Rizwan is the creator of the UX Alphabet app, a handy reference app of UX concepts. talk.title: The Power of Sketching for Developers
talk.description:
Sketching is an easily overlooked skill for developers yet the benefits that sketching brings cannot be overstated. Sketching helps with brainstorming ideas, iterating through concepts, and communicating your ideas to others. Whether working individually or in a group, your ability to sketch helps take the abstract ideas out of heads and into the real world. If you’re not comfortable sketching then there is little chance that your ideas will stick with you, your team members, and even your clients. Don’t worry—the confidence you need to put your pen to paper and start to sketch is close at hand! With the addition of a few simple approaches to your daily routine, you too can harness the power of sketching. 

Key Takeaways:
- Developers can sketch.
- Understand the benefits of sketching and why it is important for developers
- Learn specific techniques to power up your sketching skills
- See the power of sketching firsthand by taking part in sketching activities

Come prepared to do fun sketching activities in this hands-on talk so you can experience the power of sketching firsthand.
talk.notes:
The goal of my talk is to help both designers and non-designers understand the power of sketching. Everyone has great ideas to share and the faster we get them out of our heads and into the physical world the quicker we can move forward. 

Agenda of my talk:

- Talk about the power of sketching. 
- Comparison of two designers and how they approach sketching and what effects that has on their careers. 
- Tools needed to sketch. 
- Sketching Activities - I have the attendees do a few sketching activities to help them understand the power of sketching firsthand. (This has been a wild success at previous talks.)
After each activity, I have the attendees discuss the sketches with each other to help them practice talking about their sketches.
- Close out the talk by showing sketches from my 30-day sketching challenge and how it transformed my sketching skills.

I want the attendees to understand that the transformation from a little bit or not at all sketching to harnessing the power of sketching is not a long time. All it takes is some consistency and effort. I want to leave them inspired and pumped up to start sketching.
talk.abstract: The power of sketching lies in using sketching to ideate, iterate, and communicate our ideas. It is time to gain the confidence you need to sketch in person or in front of a group. By harnessing the power of sketching we all can become sketching machines.

ratings.comments: While sketching and power of diagrams is fundamental the connection of this proposal to software architecture is weak. More importantly the proposer himself also admits his lack of experience in software architecture. As such this would be a weak session to include.
Architects could use drawing practice and it may be fun. On the other hand the speaker does not seem to know is audience very well, which makes me doubtful about reception.

I see the value of sketching as a tool to create screen plays, user interaction scenarios and architectural ideas. Admiral Nelson's plan for how to take out the superior French/Spanish fleet was sketched on a napkin. That said, being good at sketching does not make you a better or worse architect, and that is why I feel a bit doubtful.

session is only about sketching with no clear connection to design.  contrast this with Simon Brown's sketching exercises, which are used as a means to teaching better modelling.  I watched the video linked and the speaker was boring, the exercises didn't seem appropriate for architectural modelling, most of them you can easily do on your own just by watching his video that is already available online.

feedback.body:
Hi Rizwan,

Thanks for your submission!  I'm a bit torn regarding your proposal.  On the one hand I agree that sketching is a useful and powerful tool.  I also enjoy sketching exercises and have seen the many positive benefits of becoming a confident sketcher - including my own 30 day sketch challenge.  On the other hand, at least with software architecture design, we are often concerned with models and reasoning.  I worry that your proposal overemphasizes sketching without a clear connection to modelling and using the sketches to reason about important system properties.

Pros I see in this talk

* Looks like a really interactive hands on session
* Presenter is passionate about the topic
* Sketching is a useful skill and something many developers could use more practice with.

Cons I see in this talk

* No clear connection to software architecture
* Risks further perpetuating boxology and "architecture is just boxes and lines" mentality with no connection to modelling or otherwise using diagrams to reason about system properties

Rizwan, What is your vision for where the sketching techniques you'll practice during the session will fit in a developer's tool box?  When and how would someone use these skills?

Regards,

Michael

Hi Michael,
I completely understand your point. Since I don't have a full grasp of the software architecture domain I would start off by getting architects to understand the power of sketching, which is using sketching for ideation, iteration, and communication of ideas. The sketching activities are designed to show them how little time it takes to sketch and that anyone can sketch. After each activity, I ask the attendees to show their sketches to a person next to them to practice using sketching to communicate.

Developers can then take this knowledge and firsthand experience and apply it to their workflow/processes the very next day. 

To make a stronger connection with the conference topic I can add a specific software architecture sketching activity. I will do some research on which activity can be included in the talk.

I hope I have answered you questions. :) I am also open to any ideas you might have as well.

Thanks,
Rizwan

Thanks, Rizwan.  Your response is helpful.

As far as helping to make a stronger connection to architecture design, you might take a look at some of the work by [Simon Brown](http://www.codingthearchitecture.com/).  He's done some things with sketching and architecture in the past and might give you some ideas for making that connection.

Regards,

Michael

I found Simon Brown's presentation on sketching for architects interesting. He makes a great connection between the why and the how of sketching and architecture design. http://www.codingthearchitecture.com/presentations/saturn2013-effective-software-architecture-sketches

One of the exercises in my talk is Rapid Sketching. In this exercise, the audience sketches the same thing six times but each time there is less time to sketch. So we start from 2 minutes to sketch and then got to 1 minute, 45 seconds, 30 seconds, 15 seconds and end with 5 seconds to sketch. I want the attendees to realize how much detail we need to represent an idea. This activity can be tweaked to use a software architecture diagram that has a lot of detail and see how much detail is needed to quickly represent it. 

I see my talk as getting people excited and inspired to begin using sketching as a tool to visually communicate their ideas. 

I can tweak the other exercises to be software architecture focused as well. 

What do you think?

Thanks,
Rizwan

profile.name: Bart Blommaerts
profile.bio:
Bart Blommaerts is a passionate Software Architect at Ordina, who believes closing the model-code gap is essential to make rapid, agile delivery sustainable. Bart has a strong focus on API design, reuse, automation and security. He is always looking for technical challenges. Bart also is the chairman of the different JWorks Competence Leads at Ordina.

Before Ordina, Bart led the EMEA Java Community at HP and was chairman of the HP Java Governance Board in the Benelux.

talk.title: 10 tips to become an awesome Technical Lead
talk.description:
As you grow in your career, chances are that one day you will end up as the Technical Lead of 1 or more projects. Often not by choice. The role of Technical Lead is quite different from the role of (senior) Software Developer and this talk will bring you answers on questions like:

* How do I do technical interviews?
* How do I lead a team? How do I lead multiple teams?
* How do I cope with my new responsibilities?
* How do I cope with success / failure?
* How do I prevent losing focus on the technical challenges?
* ...

In summary, everything you want(ed) to know on your first day as a Technical Lead and that you can use every day from that point onwards.
talk.notes:
I've been a Technical Lead for over 10 years .. a role I never requested. I worked with small teams (2 people) and with larger teams (20+ people) as a Technical Lead. And a couple of times, I needed to do some firefighting on other projects, because of the missing experience of the Technical Lead (eg. when leading a team of offshore developers).

I started a Technical Lead training program when I was back at HP to overcome issues senior developers are likely to face when becoming a Technical Lead (eg. how to do technical interviews .. Which questions are useful? Should you focus on the resume? etc. ).

I would like to share my personal experience on this topic, because I believe a good Technical Lead is a key role within most (/ all) development teams.
talk.abstract: Everything you want(ed) to know on your first day as a Technical Lead and that you can use every day from that point onwards.

ratings.comments: If the content of this talk is kept narrow enough, this would be a really interesting talk.  However like other reviewers, I don't think a 15 minute talk that turns into a list of (say) 10 items will be very effective.  Better to pick the top 3 and have something that people will remember and enough time to tell some memorable stories.
Sounds like a good talk and introduction to something software architects needs awareness on. Good fit with SATURN.

The speaker definitely has some good experience to share regarding the role of technical lead and how it interacts with the architecture role.

Unfortunately, I don't believe that the '10 tips' format is right for SATURN.  I would love to hear a talk on the topic that was more focused on an audience of architects.
I don't see the tie to Software Architecture.  If he was a Software Architecture tech lead, then I could see the relevant tie.
I would very much like to see this 15-minute talk narrowed to fewer questions, all in a single area -- any of technical reviews, dealing with people, planning, etc.
Find the topic relevant, its experienced based, but hard to see how it relate to architecture and what are the takeaway from attending the talk. I have also some doubts about 15 minutes length.
These are all interesting topics for architects as leaders but also interesting to glean from books and available leadership literature.

The topic sounds interesting and pragmatic.

However it is not clear on how the topic is related to one of the topic themes for this year's conference. 

https://www.sei.cmu.edu/saturn/2017/call.cfm

In case the author could justify and provide more clarity I would think of considering it for a short time slot.

feedback.body:
Bart-

Thanks for your submission!

Your proposal sounds interesting, but I'm concerned about squeezing 10 tips into 15 minutes. Have you given this talk before?
I'm also concerned that this topic comes up a lot in blogs and other forums - how is your talk going to be different?

Thank you.

Hi John,

Thank you for considering my proposal.

It is a brand-new talk. I will present it, for the first time, in Riga, in a 50 mins slot.
I have experience with "slicing" talks into different time frames. For a 15 mins slot, I'd focus on the key takeaways and invite those interested to discuss the 10 tips in detail after the talk. Should you prefer it, I can also do 5 tips in more detail during the slot.

My talk will be different, because all the tips will come from personal experience. I've been a technical lead for different projects (in size, budget, team composition, location, ...)  for the past 10 years and I want to share my personal "lessons learned". 

Kind regards,
Bart Blommaerts

Thanks for the proposal. The topic sounds interesting and pragmatic.

From the guidelines for the conference could you please elaborate on how the topic is related to one of the topic themes for this year's conference. Link given at the end for your reference.

One of the themes talk about “how to ensure that architecture work gets done in environments without formal architect roles”. Is the talk about role of the Team Lead in an environment with or without a formal Architect? Also, what is not fully clear is whether the talk is about some of the management related activities a technical lead need to do or much on the technical side with or without an Architect.

Similarly, there is a theme that talks about “developing software architects, including coaching, mentoring, certification, professional training, and college education”. Is that the area the topic is going top focus.

Would it make sense to split the talk on roles and responsibilities of the technical lead without the interviewing aspects, as that would allow better focus for the limited time. I am also concerned about the 15-minute time window.

https://www.sei.cmu.edu/saturn/2017/call.cfm

Hello Yogeshwar,

Thank you for your feedback. Those are really good and useful questions!

When first submitting this talk, I intended to make two versions: a high-level version, suitable for a 15 mins slot and a more in-depth version, suitable for a 50 mins slot. For Saturn, I wanted to do the high-level version and invite the attendees to discuss the different tips in detail after the talk.

However, I like your idea of splitting the talk in two talks: 
- Focus on the roles and responsibilities of the technical lead (related on "build"): eg. architecture without having a formal architect role + governance over this architecture. This is (coincidentally) exactly what I'm doing in a current Microservices project for the biggest telecom operator in Belgium (IoT project in the smart automotive area). 
- Focus on the management aspect of a technical lead: eg. the interviewing process, facilitating estimations, etc.

I can do both talks, if you would like me to. I will likely split my "in-depth" version in these two topics as well. So thanks again for your feedback.

Most content of the talk(s) will come from personal experience and I intend to give a lot of anecdotes, personal stories and of course the "lessons learned" from these.

Kind regards,
Bart Blommaerts
Thanks for the details! All the Best!

I find it relevant and interesting but is concerned with 15 minutes. I would have liked to see the five core takeaways, and how does this role relate to the architecture of the actual system?

//Einar

Hello Einar,

Thank you for considering my proposal. It appears that PaperCall does not share the questions and comments from reviewers, because I received very similar comments from Yogeshwar Srikrishnan and John Klein. But that really shows the question is spot-on :)

My initial goal was to give 10 high-level tips and then invite the interested attendees to discuss more in-depth after the talk. But after the feedback from you and your colleagues, I proposed to split the talk in two talks:

1. Focus on the roles and responsibilities of the technical lead (related to “build”): eg. architecture without having a formal architect role + governance over this architecture. This is (coincidentally) exactly what I’m doing in a current Microservices project for the biggest telecom operator in Belgium (IoT project in the smart automotive area). 

2. Focus on the management aspect of a technical lead: eg. the interviewing process, facilitating estimations, etc.

I can do both talks, or the one you and your colleagues esteem best suited.


I'd like to thank you for your feedback, because I believe its really valuable. I do hope the different reviewers share their comments and my responses to them. It would be a shame if the responses got lost, due to the way PaperCall shares them.


Kind regards,
Bart Blommaerts

Thank you for the submission. It's great to share your experience and expertise in leading architecture-related projects. This submission can fit into topics dealing with the process of architecting in either track 1 or 3.

I share the concerns of some of the other reviewers (whose comments I am able to read in PaperCall, by the way) about content versus time. I like the questions you pose in the abstract, but it may be difficult to give them all enough attention in 15 minutes for audience members to get enough information to really absorb and later apply the answers. I like the idea of splitting the talk. 

If you stick with the short, 15-minute TED-style talk, please consider focusing on fewer questions in one particular area -- any of technical reviews, dealing with people, planning, etc. Alternatively, consider expanding the  presentation to a 30-minute experience report. I realize that you have plans for two versions, and were targeting the shorter version for SATURN.

Hi Anthony,

What would Saturn prefer?

a) 30 mins talk on "10 tips"
b) 15 mins talk on 5 "technical" tips
c) 15 mins talk on 5 "management" tips

I can do 2 talks (b and c) if Saturn would like me to. All content will be influenced a lot by my personal experiences. I never had the opportunity to attend Saturn, so it's difficult to determine the best match with the above choices. I'll happily write two abstracts (b and c) if needed.

Regards,
Bart Blommaerts

Hi Bart,

I'd expect either (b) or (c) to work out best. Other reviewers, please add your thoughts.

You have more information too, so if you find you have more time during the talk, you can always add a bonus tip or two. No one will complain if you advertise five tips and deliver six or seven!.

I'm hoping to hear what experience or problem led to each situation and what resulting tip resolves the problem. I want to hear more than just a flat list of tips. I want to hear your great stories behind them.

Hey Anthony,

Spot on. The number is actually not 10 tips .. but that's the first tip :)


Bart

Hi Bart,

This talk sounds interesting but appears to be aimed at new technical leads rather than architects.

As an experienced architect what do you think that you would take away from this presentation?

In your description you hint at an interesting architectural perspective regarding the importance of the role, such as the firefighting required due to the lack of good technical leads.

Is it possible to re-frame the talk to aim it more specifically at the architect?  For example, what roles do you think the architect plays in the development of good technical leads?  Do you believe that developing technical leads is an essential step towards developing good architects?#

Regards, 


Ged

Hi Ged,

I believe an architect needs to be part of the team, responsible for "creating" the system. In agile projects, this means being part of every sprint that needs architecturally significant decisions. In order to do this successful, a good collaboration between the technical lead and the architect is necessary. What I've regularly seem in practice, is that both roles are not always present in the same team: some projects might be to small (budget, man days, scope, ...) while many others are organised sub-optimal. One of your review-colleagues also pointed this out.

Both roles have some things in common (eg. leadership) and some of the tips I want to provide, should assist in creating this synergy: as a technical lead pay attention to architectural decisions, collaborate on the decision-making process. Get involved. You can see that this requires a different approach with or without a formal architectural role. I too often saw technical leads putting all their focus on "tools" and "frameworks" and I believe this alone is not enough to deliver successful systems (and sometimes it can be enough). Leadership is about being able to delegate, collaborate (with architects, developers, business people, ... stakeholders). An architect should embrace working with a technical lead, guide him, elevate him. And a technical lead should also embrace working with an architect: support him with technical options, ...

I strongly believe collaboration will aid both roles to perform better and become better. The roles have both similarities and differences. And that's a really good thing.

Regards,
Bart Blommaerts

Hi Bart,

Thanks for replying.  I completely agree regarding the importance of good collaboration between the roles.

Regards, 


Ged

talk.title: Accessibility Testing Tools for Developers
talk.description:
You don't have to be an accessibility expert to make your projects accessible, but you do have to make your projects accessible. 

Identifying accessibility issues as early as possible can save an organization or project a substantial amount of money, time, and headaches over trying to augment a web site or application after initial development. Using a testing tools during development for accessibility will definitely help with this process. 

For developers that are novice to web accessibility this presentation is a great introduction into key aspects to consider while developing. For developers that are more familiar, this presentation exposes tools that will make accessibility easier. All users will gain from learning how to build accessibility into their development workflow using a variety of testing tools, from simple to intricate.
talk.notes: This is generally a 60 minute presentation that can easily be expanded to fill 90 minutes.
talk.abstract: You don't have to be an accessibility expert to make your projects accessible, but you do have to make your projects accessible. This presentation can serve as an introduction to web accessibility by exposing what to look for, via a variety of tools, to help developers make projects inclusive to all
talk.talk_format: Tech Talks and Tech Tutorials (30 or 90 minutes - please specify the exact time in the Notes section)

ratings.comments: I think this would perhaps fit in a 30 minute presentation. 90 minutes are probably to long. If condensed into a 30 minute talk for architects, it would be a good fit for SATURN.

I think the topic of accessibility testing is valuable and architects should have exposure to it.  But at present it is hard to tell what you're going to cover, whether it will be relevant to me and what I'll learn. 

Can you extend the description to provide more information on what the talk actually covers?  Given that it can be 60 or 90 minutes, it would also be worth clarifying what you would include or exclude in the two forms.

I would love to hear a talk on Accessibility from an architectural perspective.  Something to spark more discussion regarding this quality attribute. 

Unfortunately this talk appears to be focused on development, which is of less interest.
I don't see the tie to software architecture.

I find this topic relevant. There is a question if it should be done as an introduction, aimed at architects or more as a in depth workshop aimed at coders. 

What are the you guys thinking?
Topic is relevant and important. Details for a 90 minute slot are sparse.

feedback.body:
Hi Einar, thank you for your consideration. Perhaps an intro to web accessibility would be better suited, if you feel it is a unknown subject to the audience? If not, I can gladly add a few lines to describe the purpose and benefits.

Regarding the duration, 90 minutes would allow me more time to go through the code demonstration at then end, the gran finale, which is usually rushed due to questions/ conversations throughout the presentation.

Please let me know if you need additional information. Again, thank you for your consideration.

Thank you Gerard. It might be the case that a introduction is better. There are more software architects than programmers here. But lets see what the other PC members think. In its current form, I think a 90 minute workshop is better than a 60 minutes. In introduction to the topic I guess is better done in 30 minutes.

Einar, since there are more architects than programmers then maybe this isn't the right forum for my presentation? My presentations on web accessibility are for front-end engineers using HTML, CSS, and JS that impact end-users. Software architect are a little too high level for this information. Thoughts?

Hi Gerard,

As an architect I'm curious, because I believe that accessibility is such an important quality attribute.  However, I'm not so interested in the implementation details.

I would love to see a talk provide an good, practical overview of the topic for the architect.  This is an area of debate for architects, so I think it is a very relevant field for discussion.

For example, in the first addition of "Software Architecture in Practice" the statement was made: "Making a system's user interface clear and easy to use is primarily a matter of getting the details of a user's interaction correct … but these details are not architectural."

In later editions this position was retracted with a section called "Usability Mea Culpa (or that’s not Architecture)" but other architects still disagree.  Consider this blog post that insists that usability is important, but still not architecture: http://enterprise-it-architecture.blogspot.co.uk/2013/04/usability-is-not-architecture-quality.html

As somebody with a passion for and experience of achieving accessibility, could you explain to architects why this is an important quality attribute and the role that architects play in improving it?

If you could include some well defined quality scenarios [1] and relevant architectural tactics [2] that would be very desirable.  The testing approach would be covered by the tactics and you might want to focus on this in particular.

I appreciate that this would be quite a deviation from your current proposal.  You may think of something closer to what you already have that will help to convince architects that this is something they need to be interested in.

[1] http://www.informit.com/articles/article.aspx?p=1959673&seqNum=4
[2] http://www.informit.com/articles/article.aspx?p=1959673&seqNum=5

Hi Ged,

I can understand why architects do not feel that usability, or UI, belongs in the realm of architecture. I can tell you from my own personal experiences that bad/ lazy service architecture can definitely impact and lead to bad UI. A lot of times, these things are in the name of security or performance and sometimes they can be smoothed over on the front end, but most times they can't. Speaking as a Front-End architect, performance is just as much a part of usability as accessibility is. 

I would agree that implementation of accessibility will not be of any interest to most architects, unless they are front-end like myself. But if you are interested in having the discussion of how bad architecture could lead to bad usability, I certainly have a few anecdotes that I could share.

There was a great [talk on globalization last year at SATURN](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KPabgSykvD8&list=PLSNlEg26NNpy1RjhlISNMRNO1gypYaXHo).  I like the idea of talks that try to find connections between architecture design and UX design.

Having gone through some accessibility training I do think there are architectural concerns and many of the trade-offs Gerard mentioned come to bear.  At the same time, it seems that most of web accessibility is related to implementation details - color choice, proper tagging, good naming, navigation orders for JAWS, etc.

I think the goal for most SATURN attendees would not be to become an accessibility expert, but to learn enough to not make bad trade-offs as Gerard mentioned (e.g. security over accessibility) or at least be aware that trade-offs are happening.  The proposed talk will go into significant detail that I don't think will be of general interest.  I realize that's a little sad since this is an important topic.  I think a shorter talk that gives a good overview and emphasizes the top things an architect should know might be a better fit for the audience.

Gerard -- What are your thoughts for your proposal based on the feedback?  I do hope some of the feedback was helpful.

Regards,

Michael

profile.name: Babu Samuel
profile.bio: I have been working in IT for about 20 years. For the past 7 years, I am working as an architect and a technical lead in SIEMENS healthineers at Princeton, New Jersey.

talk.title: Agile With Architecture
talk.description:
Over the past few years, there is a question central to many discussions surrounding agile approaches to architecting software: In agile process, is the architecture of the system designed up-front, or does it emerge over time as the result of the agile software development process? Also there is an importance of supporting evolution and change to a software-intensive system, and the practical implications of creating a change-ready system. The ability to adapt these changes is driven by two factors, Architecture and Agile Practices. This presentation shows some of the techniques an architect can use to be effective in the fast moving agile environments.
1.	A hybrid form combining both explicit and emergent architectural techniques. This approach explains
	      (i) How alignment is the part of architectural work where an architect makes sure that the solution fits its mission?
	      (ii) How distilling the direction of change, and designing the domain essence are explicit architectural activities?
	      (iii) How creating the detailed structure, and designing the domain essence can be done in an emergent way
2.	Trace the history of software development practices from waterfall phases through iterative design to agile techniques. These include
	      (i)The implementation of a project lifecycle selection framework
	      (ii) An approach for tailoring any defined method
	      (iii) A consideration of all elements of a development environment
	      (iv) Incremental adoption of change

feedback.body:
Thank you for the submission. Agile architecting is a topic of interest as development times continue to shorten.

Could you explain more about what type of agile development you are addressing? You have mention "agile software development process" (lowercase agile) and "Agile Practices" (uppercase Agile). There can be differences, and audience members may make incorrect assumptions. Will the talk address how architecting activities relate to some specific Agile methods (for example, sprints) or is it more about architecting in a less strictly defined but still rapidly changing environment?

It may be difficult to present all the proposed content in 15 minutes. The abstract describes five topics, some with subtopics. If you need to shorten it, I suggest that the history information (waterfall to iterative to agile) could be trimmed out. That is information audience members can find in other places (for example, on the Web).

How you specifically combined architecting tasks and work produces with agile timelines, and how you are able to continually revise the architecture without big tear ups and lost work will be most valuable to audience members. I suggest a focus on those aspects (that is, your topic 3).

For which track is this talk proposed? Track 1 or 3 seem applicable.

Thank you for the feedback. Please see below my answers to your questions.

In this topic, I was trying to address how architecting activities relate to Agile Software Development (ASD) methods (for example Scrum). In other words  how architects can be effective in iterative, incremental and evolutionary development . I agree that it is difficult to cover the topics I put in my abstract in 15 minutes. So I am thinking of concentrating what you proposed which is mostly on topic 3. So here I will concentrate more on how to continually revise the architecture without big tear ups and lost work or how to avoid design erosion.  

I think this will fit on Track 1 (how architects can be effective in fast-moving, agile environments)

So here is my revised abstract on this topic.

Over the past few years, there is a question central to many discussions surrounding agile approaches to architecting software: In agile process, is the architecture of the system designed up-front, or does it emerge over time as the result of the agile software development process such as Scrum? However, according to the followers of Agile Software Development (ASD) methods, upfront design and evaluation of Software Architecture are likely to consume lot of time and effort without providing a valuable deliverables. The proponents of Software Architecture believe that sound architectural practices cannot be followed using agile approaches. This presentation shows how software architects embrace change by systematically altering design activities with iterative architecture assessment and refactoring.
Thanks for the reply! Good luck!

I like the revised focus as it relates to a significant challenge for software development. Would you say a little more about your “different perspective?” Does this relate to any other tools/techniques that would give the reviewers a sense of your approach (for example, there has been a lot of attention lately to addressing the challenges if ASD with scaled agile frameworks). Relating how the technique helps you with challenges you are facing on your current projects is an effective way to communicate your story. Would you say a little more, perhaps about an anecdote that you might use?

Can you confirm that this is intended as a 15 minute talk? We have had some issues with talk format being changed on edit. Please updated your submission to indicate the correct talk format and note the length in the Notes section as well.

DEV@SATURN Talk (15 minutes)


Audience Level
Intermediate
You are nailing it down, but 15 minutes is not a long time. You have basically 5 slides, what are the titles on those slides.

Basically in this talk I am going to talk about the "Variability" technique which we follow in our projects to adapt change in ASD.
Variability is interpreted as "anticipated and preplanned change" which is identified by looking into a number of similar but not identical systems from different usage or deployment scenarios.

The following are the titles for the 5 slides which I am planning.

Slide 1: Introduction of Variability Technique (i.e., locations in the architecture where change might occur)

Slides 2-5 are for handling variability.

Slide 2: Architectural Analysis (explains how to conduct initial variability analysis and create initial variability profile)

Slide 3: Architectural Synthesis (explains about proposing architecture solutions for the architecturally significant requirements identified during architectural analysis)

Slide 4: Architectural Evaluation (explains about examining architectural decisions against architecturally significant requirements)

Slide 5: Architectural Implementation and Maintenance  (explains about implementing initial architecture, elicitation of new variability requirements, revising architecture variability profile and refactoring architecture)

talk.title: An invisible app? An Introduction to Inclusive Design & Fundamental User Experience Best Practices
talk.description:
An invisible app? An Introduction to Inclusive Design & Fundamental User Experience Best Practices
I know what you're thinking. You want to know what the triple-A app titles already know. It's Inclusive Design, a process to deliver intuitive usability; it is the heart-and-soul of great User Experience and innovative interactions. Your app is in a cosmic battle with the Uninstall button; inclusive design changes the nature of your app, tipping the scales in your favor. Appeal to your largest audience, provide cohesive experiences, and reduce development costs. It is an investment with one of the best returns in all of software. It's simple, cheap and awesome.

Application security is fundamental to software from initial design to every line developed. Security should not be an afterthought. Similarly, usability has this same ubiquity throughout the life-cycle of software. The fastest, most secure, most scalable software can end up in the trash because it misses the most important success criteria for any program in the universe - user acceptance. Software architecture profoundly impacts usability. Usability profoundly impacts acceptance. Architects may not choose app colors, error messages, and device layout, but they certainly make choices that enable and constrain designers options that make our software better. Like security is everyone’s responsibility at some level, so is usability at some level.

What will attendees learn? Inclusive design isn’t only usability; it’s recognizing that your user base changes as their social and environmental contexts change. If your user is standing in the sun, waiting for a train in the snow, holding a baby, riding a bus, visiting a library or watching the big game in a sports bar, applications can account for the one type of user that, given a certain context, looks and acts like another type of user. Inclusive design helps developers understand these contexts. It applies these to our implementations to add modalities, flexibility in workflows, and intentional tolerance for user mistakes. Developers will learn to recognize contextual assumptions and apply new, potential contexts to their existing user base so they can serve them best while consequently serving a new, larger user base.
talk.notes:
This is a 90 minute talk.

The structure of the talk includes:
1. Introduction to basic user types
2. Introduction to core user contexts
3. Examples of design assumptions
4. Examples of coding mistakes
5. Examples of app wins
6. Easy changes to the UI you can make today
7. Easy changes to the code you can make today
8.  Fundamental changes to code you can make next time

In the notes section, consider including an outline of your talk, even if it’s only tentative.

This is really great feedback. Consider security. It is fundamental to software from initial design to every line developed. Security is not an afterthought. Similarly, usability has this ubiquity throughout the life-cycle of software. The fastest, most secure, most scalable software can end up in the trash because it misses the most important success criteria for any program in the universe - user acceptance. Software architecture profoundly impacts usability. Usability profoundly impacts acceptance. Though architects may not choose app colors, error messages, and device layout, they certainly make choices that enable or constrain designers and the options they might employ. Like security is everyone's responsibility, so is usability. Inclusive design, on the other hand isn't only about usability; it's about recognizing that your user base changes as their social and environmental contexts change. If your user is standing in the sun, waiting for a train in the snow, holding a baby, riding a bus, visiting a library or watching the big game in a sports bar, applications can account for the one type of user given a certain context looks and acts like another type of user. Inclusive design helps developers understand these contexts and apply them to the implementation of their software for to add more modalities, flexibility in workflows, and intentional tolerance for user mistakes.

I wanted to reply one quick thing to John about the word "design". I did not make up the term Inclusive Design, and I understand the word design has a meaning to developers and designers. But I can't change it because it's the real name of the approach. I added a lot of context in the description that I hope will make it clear to developers that this is for developers and not designers (designers would likely appreciate the content). And this is about using our development decisions to make the design better. I hope this makes sense.

talk.title: Concourse : Fly the Friendly CI
talk.description:
Continuous Deployment and Continous Integration are important aspects in modern software development lifecycle, however it is notoriously hard to scale your CI/CD efforts and resources. 

Concourse CI is a Simple, Scalable, and Open Source CI system which aims to solve some of the common struggles teams face when scaling CI for large agile teams deploying to multi-cloud infrastructures. This talk will deep dive into Concourse’s internal workings, and how it can help solve  a range of real world problems and use cases involved in CD/CI testing.

Ahh, I figured out the problem; PaperCall mapped their "formats" to yours and what was listed as "Talk - (~30-45 minutes)" submitted as "DEV@SATURN Talk ". I changed it to the format "Other" and that made it "Tech Talks and Tech Tutorials (30 or 90 minutes)"

Hi Topher,

I think this topic could be very relevant to the SATURN audience but I worry that the lessons and analysis may be too tied to the specific tool you mentioned, Concourse CI.
